统计场论第九章

9

Dissipative dynamics

9.1 Brownian motion of a particle

Observations under a microscope indicate that a dust particle in a liquid drop undergoes a random jittery motion. This is because of the random impacts of the much smaller fluid particles. The theory of such (Brownian) motion was developed by Einstein in 1905 and starts with the equation of motion for the particle [A. Einstein, Ann. d. Physik 17, 549 (1905)]. The displacement x⃗(t)\vec{x}(t)x(t), of a particle of mass mmm is governed by

mx⃗¨=−x⃗˙μ−∂V∂x⃗+f⃗random (t)\begin{equation*} m \ddot{\vec{x}}=-\frac{\dot{\vec{x}}}{\mu}-\frac{\partial \mathcal{V}}{\partial \vec{x}}+\vec{f}_{\text {random }}(t) \tag{9.1} \end{equation*}mx¨=−μx˙​−∂x∂V​+f​random ​(t)​(9.1)​

The three forces acting on the particle are: (1) A friction force due to the viscosity of the fluid. For a spherical particle of radius RRR, the mobility in the low Reynolds number limit is given by μ=(6πηˉR)−1\mu=(6 \pi \bar{\eta} R)^{-1}μ=(6πηˉ​R)−1, where ηˉ\bar{\eta}ηˉ​ is the specific viscosity. (2) The force due to the external potential V(x⃗)\mathcal{V}(\vec{x})V(x), e.g. gravity. (3) A random force of zero mean due to the impacts of fluid particles.

The viscous term usually dominates the inertial one (i.e. the motion is overdamped), and we shall henceforth ignore the acceleration term. Equation (9.1) now reduces to the Langevin equation,

x⃗˙=v⃗(x⃗)+η⃗(t),\begin{equation*} \dot{\vec{x}}=\vec{v}(\vec{x})+\vec{\eta}(t), \tag{9.2} \end{equation*}x˙=v(x)+η​(t),​(9.2)​

where v⃗(x⃗)=−μ∂V/∂x⃗\vec{v}(\vec{x})=-\mu \partial \mathcal{V} / \partial \vec{x}v(x)=−μ∂V/∂x is the deterministic velocity. The stochastic velocity, η⃗(t)=μf⃗random (t)\vec{\eta}(t)=\mu \vec{f}_{\text {random }}(t)η​(t)=μf​random ​(t), has zero mean,

⟨η⃗(t)⟩=0.\begin{equation*} \langle\vec{\eta}(t)\rangle=0 . \tag{9.3} \end{equation*}⟨η​(t)⟩=0.​(9.3)​

It is usually assumed that the probability distribution for the noise in velocity is Gaussian, i.e.

P[η⃗(t)]∝exp⁡[−∫dτη(τ)24D].\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}[\vec{\eta}(t)] \propto \exp \left[-\int \mathrm{d} \tau \frac{\eta(\tau)^{2}}{4 D}\right] . \tag{9.4} \end{equation*}P[η​(t)]∝exp[−∫dτ4Dη(τ)2​].​(9.4)​

Note that different components of the noise, and at different times, are independent, and the covariance is

⟨ηα(t)ηβ(t′)⟩=2Dδαβδ(t−t′)\begin{equation*} \left\langle\eta_{\alpha}(t) \eta_{\beta}\left(t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=2 D \delta_{\alpha \beta} \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) \tag{9.5} \end{equation*}⟨ηα​(t)ηβ​(t′)⟩=2Dδαβ​δ(t−t′)​(9.5)​

The parameter DDD is related to diffusion of particles in the fluid. In the absence of any potential, V(x⃗)=0\mathcal{V}(\vec{x})=0V(x)=0, the position of a particle at time ttt is given by

x⃗(t)=x⃗(0)+∫0t dτη⃗(τ)\vec{x}(t)=\vec{x}(0)+\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau \vec{\eta}(\tau)x(t)=x(0)+∫0t​ dτη​(τ)

Clearly the separation x⃗(t)−x⃗(0)\vec{x}(t)-\vec{x}(0)x(t)−x(0) which is the sum of random Gaussian variables is itself Gaussian distributed with mean zero, and a variance

⟨(x⃗(t)−x⃗(0))2⟩=∫0t dτ1 dτ2⟨η⃗(τ1)⋅η⃗(τ2)⟩=3×2Dt\left\langle(\vec{x}(t)-\vec{x}(0))^{2}\right\rangle=\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau_{1} \mathrm{~d} \tau_{2}\left\langle\vec{\eta}\left(\tau_{1}\right) \cdot \vec{\eta}\left(\tau_{2}\right)\right\rangle=3 \times 2 D t⟨(x(t)−x(0))2⟩=∫0t​ dτ1​ dτ2​⟨η​(τ1​)⋅η​(τ2​)⟩=3×2Dt

For an ensemble of particles released at x⃗(t)=0\vec{x}(t)=0x(t)=0, i.e. with P(x⃗,t=0)=δ3(x⃗)\mathcal{P}(\vec{x}, t=0)=\delta^{3}(\vec{x})P(x,t=0)=δ3(x), the particles at time ttt are distributed according to

P(x⃗,t)=(14πDt)3/2exp⁡[−x24Dt]\mathcal{P}(\vec{x}, t)=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi D t}}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{4 D t}\right]P(x,t)=(4πDt​1​)3/2exp[−4Dtx2​]

which is the solution to the diffusion equation

∂P∂t=D∇2P\frac{\partial \mathcal{P}}{\partial t}=D \nabla^{2} \mathcal{P}∂t∂P​=D∇2P

A simple example is provided by a particle connected to a Hookian spring, with V(x⃗)=Kx2/2\mathcal{V}(\vec{x})=K x^{2} / 2V(x)=Kx2/2. The deterministic velocity is now v⃗(x⃗)=−μKx⃗\vec{v}(\vec{x})=-\mu K \vec{x}v(x)=−μKx, and the Langevin equation, x⃗˙=−μKx⃗+η⃗(t)\dot{\vec{x}}=-\mu K \vec{x}+\vec{\eta}(t)x˙=−μKx+η​(t), can be rearranged as

d dt[eμKtx⃗(t)]=eμKtη⃗(t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t}\left[\mathrm{e}^{\mu K t} \vec{x}(t)\right]=\mathrm{e}^{\mu K t} \vec{\eta}(t) \tag{9.6} \end{equation*} dtd​[eμKtx(t)]=eμKtη​(t)​(9.6)​

Integrating the equation from 0 to ttt yields

eμKtx⃗(t)−x⃗(0)=∫0t dτeμKτη⃗(τ)\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{\mu K t} \vec{x}(t)-\vec{x}(0)=\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{e}^{\mu K \tau} \vec{\eta}(\tau) \tag{9.7} \end{equation*}eμKtx(t)−x(0)=∫0t​ dτeμKτη​(τ)​(9.7)​

and

x⃗(t)=x⃗(0)e−μKt+∫0t dτe−μK(t−τ)η⃗(τ)\begin{equation*} \vec{x}(t)=\vec{x}(0) \mathrm{e}^{-\mu K t}+\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{e}^{-\mu K(t-\tau)} \vec{\eta}(\tau) \tag{9.8} \end{equation*}x(t)=x(0)e−μKt+∫0t​ dτe−μK(t−τ)η​(τ)​(9.8)​

Averaging over the noise indicates that the mean position,

⟨x⃗(t)⟩=x⃗(0)e−μKt\begin{equation*} \langle\vec{x}(t)\rangle=\vec{x}(0) \mathrm{e}^{-\mu K t} \tag{9.9} \end{equation*}⟨x(t)⟩=x(0)e−μKt​(9.9)​

decays with a characteristic relaxation time, τ=1/(μK)\tau=1 /(\mu K)τ=1/(μK). Fluctuations around the mean behave as

⟨(x⃗(t)−⟨x⃗(t)⟩)2⟩=∫0t dτ1 dτ2e−μK(2t−τ1−τ2)⟨η⃗(τ1)⋅η⃗(τ2)⟩⏞2Dδ(τ1−τ2)×3=6D∫0t dτe−2μK(t−τ)=3DμK[1−e−2μKt]→t→∞3DμK.\begin{align*} \left\langle(\vec{x}(t)-\langle\vec{x}(t)\rangle)^{2}\right\rangle & =\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau_{1} \mathrm{~d} \tau_{2} \mathrm{e}^{-\mu K\left(2 t-\tau_{1}-\tau_{2}\right)} \overbrace{\left\langle\vec{\eta}\left(\tau_{1}\right) \cdot \vec{\eta}\left(\tau_{2}\right)\right\rangle}^{2 D \delta\left(\tau_{1}-\tau_{2}\right) \times 3} \\ & =6 D \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{e}^{-2 \mu K(t-\tau)} \tag{9.10}\\ & =\frac{3 D}{\mu K}\left[1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 \mu K t}\right] \xrightarrow{t \rightarrow \infty} \frac{3 D}{\mu K} . \end{align*}⟨(x(t)−⟨x(t)⟩)2⟩​=∫0t​ dτ1​ dτ2​e−μK(2t−τ1​−τ2​)⟨η​(τ1​)⋅η​(τ2​)⟩​2Dδ(τ1​−τ2​)×3​=6D∫0t​ dτe−2μK(t−τ)=μK3D​[1−e−2μKt]t→∞​μK3D​.​(9.10)​

However, once the dust particle reaches equilibrium with the fluid at a temperature TTT, its probability distribution must satisfy the normalized Boltzmann weight

Peq. .(x⃗)=(K2πkBT)3/2exp⁡[−Kx22kBT],\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}_{\text {eq. }} .(\vec{x})=\left(\frac{K}{2 \pi k_{\mathrm{B}} T}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left[-\frac{K x^{2}}{2 k_{\mathrm{B}} T}\right], \tag{9.11} \end{equation*}Peq. ​.(x)=(2πkB​TK​)3/2exp[−2kB​TKx2​],​(9.11)​

yielding ⟨x2⟩=3kBT/K\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle=3 k_{\mathrm{B}} T / K⟨x2⟩=3kB​T/K. Since the dynamics is expected to bring the particle to equilibrium with the fluid at temperature TTT, Eq. (9.1) implies the condition

D=kBTμ\begin{equation*} D=k_{\mathrm{B}} T \mu \tag{9.12} \end{equation*}D=kB​Tμ​(9.12)​

This is the Einstein relation connecting the fluctuations of noise to the dissipation in the medium.

Clearly the Langevin equation at long times reproduces the correct mean and variance for a particle in equilibrium at a temperature TTT in the potential V(x⃗)=Kx2/2\mathcal{V}(\vec{x})=K x^{2} / 2V(x)=Kx2/2, provided that Eq. (9.12) is satisfied. Can we show that the whole probability distribution evolves to the Boltzmann weight for any potential? Let P(x⃗,t)≡⟨x⃗∣P(t)∣0⟩\mathcal{P}(\vec{x}, t) \equiv\langle\vec{x}| \mathcal{P}(t)|0\rangleP(x,t)≡⟨x∣P(t)∣0⟩ denote the probability density of finding the particle at x⃗\vec{x}x at time ttt, given that it was at 0 at t=0t=0t=0. This probability can be constructed recursively by noting that a particle found at x⃗\vec{x}x at time t+ϵt+\epsilont+ϵ must have arrived from some other point x⃗′\vec{x}^{\prime}x′ at ttt. Adding up all such probabilities yields

P(x⃗,t+ϵ)=∫d3x⃗′P(x⃗′,t)⟨x⃗∣Tϵ∣x⃗′⟩,\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}(\vec{x}, t+\epsilon)=\int \mathrm{d}^{3} \vec{x}^{\prime} \mathcal{P}\left(\vec{x}^{\prime}, t\right)\langle\vec{x}| T_{\epsilon}\left|\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\rangle, \tag{9.13} \end{equation*}P(x,t+ϵ)=∫d3x′P(x′,t)⟨x∣Tϵ​∣x′⟩,​(9.13)​

where ⟨x⃗∣Tϵ∣x⃗′⟩≡⟨x⃗∣P(ϵ)∣x⃗′⟩\langle\vec{x}| T_{\epsilon}\left|\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\rangle \equiv\langle\vec{x}| \mathcal{P}(\epsilon)\left|\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\rangle⟨x∣Tϵ​∣x′⟩≡⟨x∣P(ϵ)∣x′⟩ is the transition probability. For ϵ≪1\epsilon \ll 1ϵ≪1,

x⃗=x⃗′+v⃗(x⃗′)ϵ+η⃗ϵ,\begin{equation*} \vec{x}=\vec{x}^{\prime}+\vec{v}\left(\vec{x}^{\prime}\right) \epsilon+\vec{\eta}_{\epsilon}, \tag{9.14} \end{equation*}x=x′+v(x′)ϵ+η​ϵ​,​(9.14)​

where η⃗ϵ=∫tt+ϵdτη⃗(τ)\vec{\eta}_{\epsilon}=\int_{t}^{t+\epsilon} \mathrm{d} \tau \vec{\eta}(\tau)η​ϵ​=∫tt+ϵ​dτη​(τ). Clearly, ⟨η⃗ϵ⟩=0\left\langle\vec{\eta}_{\epsilon}\right\rangle=0⟨η​ϵ​⟩=0, and ⟨ηϵ2⟩=2Dϵ×3\left\langle\eta_{\epsilon}^{2}\right\rangle=2 D \epsilon \times 3⟨ηϵ2​⟩=2Dϵ×3, and following Eq. (9.4),

p(η⃗ϵ)=(14πDϵ)3/2exp⁡[−ηϵ24Dϵ].\begin{equation*} p\left(\vec{\eta}_{\epsilon}\right)=\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi D \epsilon}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left[-\frac{\eta_{\epsilon}^{2}}{4 D \epsilon}\right] . \tag{9.15} \end{equation*}p(η​ϵ​)=(4πDϵ1​)3/2exp[−4Dϵηϵ2​​].​(9.15)​

The transition rate is simply the probability of finding a noise of the right magnitude according to Eq. (9.14), and

⟨x⃗∣T(ϵ)∣x⃗′⟩=p(ηϵ)=(14πDϵ)3/2exp⁡[−(x⃗−x⃗′−ϵv⃗(x⃗′))24Dϵ]\langle\vec{x}| T(\epsilon)\left|\vec{x}^{\prime}\right\rangle=p\left(\eta_{\epsilon}\right)=\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi D \epsilon}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left[-\frac{\left(\vec{x}-\vec{x}^{\prime}-\epsilon \vec{v}\left(\vec{x}^{\prime}\right)\right)^{2}}{4 D \epsilon}\right]⟨x∣T(ϵ)∣x′⟩=p(ηϵ​)=(4πDϵ1​)3/2exp[−4Dϵ(x−x′−ϵv(x′))2​]
=(14πDϵ)3/2exp⁡[−ϵ(x⃗˙−v⃗(x⃗))24D]\begin{equation*} =\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi D \epsilon}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left[-\epsilon \frac{(\dot{\vec{x}}-\vec{v}(\vec{x}))^{2}}{4 D}\right] \tag{9.16} \end{equation*}=(4πDϵ1​)3/2exp[−ϵ4D(x˙−v(x))2​]​(9.16)​

By subdividing the time interval ttt into infinitesimal segments of size ϵ\epsilonϵ, repeated application of the above evolution operator yields

P(x⃗,t)=⟨x⃗∣T(ϵ)t/ϵ∣0⟩=∫(0,0)(x⃗,t)Dx⃗(τ)Nexp⁡[−∫0t dτ(x⃗˙−v⃗(x⃗))24D]\begin{align*} \mathcal{P}(\vec{x}, t) & =\langle\vec{x}| T(\epsilon)^{t / \epsilon}|0\rangle \\ & =\int_{(0,0)}^{(\vec{x}, t)} \frac{\mathcal{D} \vec{x}(\tau)}{\mathcal{N}} \exp \left[-\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau \frac{(\dot{\vec{x}}-\vec{v}(\vec{x}))^{2}}{4 D}\right] \tag{9.17} \end{align*}P(x,t)​=⟨x∣T(ϵ)t/ϵ∣0⟩=∫(0,0)(x,t)​NDx(τ)​exp[−∫0t​ dτ4D(x˙−v(x))2​]​(9.17)​

The integral is over all paths connecting the initial and final points; each path's weight is related to its deviation from the classical trajectory, x⃗˙=v⃗(x⃗)\dot{\vec{x}}=\vec{v}(\vec{x})x˙=v(x). The recursion relation in Eq. (9.13) can now be written as

P(x⃗,t)=∫d3x⃗′(14πDϵ)3/2exp⁡[−(x⃗−x⃗′−ϵv⃗(x⃗′))24Dϵ]P(x⃗′,t−ϵ),\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}(\vec{x}, t)=\int \mathrm{d}^{3} \vec{x}^{\prime}\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi D \epsilon}\right)^{3 / 2} \exp \left[-\frac{\left(\vec{x}-\vec{x}^{\prime}-\epsilon \vec{v}\left(\vec{x}^{\prime}\right)\right)^{2}}{4 D \epsilon}\right] \mathcal{P}\left(\vec{x}^{\prime}, t-\epsilon\right), \tag{9.18} \end{equation*}P(x,t)=∫d3x′(4πDϵ1​)3/2exp[−4Dϵ(x−x′−ϵv(x′))2​]P(x′,t−ϵ),​(9.18)​

and simplified by the change of variables,

y⃗=x⃗′+ϵv⃗(x⃗′)−x⃗⟹ d3y⃗=d3x⃗′(1+ϵ∇⋅v⃗(x⃗′))=d3x⃗′(1+ϵ∇⋅v⃗(x⃗)+O(ϵ2))\begin{align*} \vec{y} & =\vec{x}^{\prime}+\epsilon \vec{v}\left(\vec{x}^{\prime}\right)-\vec{x} \Longrightarrow \\ \mathrm{~d}^{3} \vec{y} & =\mathrm{d}^{3} \vec{x}^{\prime}\left(1+\epsilon \nabla \cdot \vec{v}\left(\vec{x}^{\prime}\right)\right)=\mathrm{d}^{3} \vec{x}^{\prime}\left(1+\epsilon \nabla \cdot \vec{v}(\vec{x})+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)\right) \tag{9.19} \end{align*}y​ d3y​​=x′+ϵv(x′)−x⟹=d3x′(1+ϵ∇⋅v(x′))=d3x′(1+ϵ∇⋅v(x)+O(ϵ2))​(9.19)​

Keeping only terms at order of ϵ\epsilonϵ, we obtain

P(x⃗,t)=[1−ϵ∇⋅v⃗(x⃗)]∫d3y⃗(14πDϵ)3/2e−y24P(x⃗+y⃗−ϵv⃗(x⃗),t−ϵ)=[1−ϵ∇⋅v⃗(x⃗)]∫d3y⃗(14πDϵ)3/2e−y24Dϵ×[P(x⃗,t)+(y⃗−ϵv⃗(x⃗))⋅∇P+yiyj−2ϵyivj+ϵ2vivj2∇i∇jP−ϵ∂P∂t+O(ϵ2)]=[1−ϵ∇⋅v⃗(x⃗)][P−ϵv⃗⋅∇+ϵD∇2P−ϵ∂P∂t+O(ϵ2)].\begin{align*} \mathcal{P}(\vec{x}, t) & =[1-\epsilon \nabla \cdot \vec{v}(\vec{x})] \int \mathrm{d}^{3} \vec{y}\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi D \epsilon}\right)^{3 / 2} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{y^{2}}{4 \mathcal{}} \mathcal{P}(\vec{x}+\vec{y}-\epsilon \vec{v}(\vec{x}), t-\epsilon)} \\ & =[1-\epsilon \nabla \cdot \vec{v}(\vec{x})] \int \mathrm{d}^{3} \vec{y}\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi D \epsilon}\right)^{3 / 2} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{y^{2}}{4 D \epsilon}} \\ & \times\left[\mathcal{P}(\vec{x}, t)+(\vec{y}-\epsilon \vec{v}(\vec{x})) \cdot \nabla \mathcal{P}+\frac{y_{i} y_{j}-2 \epsilon y_{i} v_{j}+\epsilon^{2} v_{i} v_{j}}{2} \nabla_{i} \nabla_{j} \mathcal{P}-\epsilon \frac{\partial \mathcal{P}}{\partial t}+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)\right] \\ & =[1-\epsilon \nabla \cdot \vec{v}(\vec{x})]\left[\mathcal{P}-\epsilon \vec{v} \cdot \nabla+\epsilon D \nabla^{2} \mathcal{P}-\epsilon \frac{\partial \mathcal{P}}{\partial t}+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)\right] . \tag{9.20} \end{align*}P(x,t)​=[1−ϵ∇⋅v(x)]∫d3y​(4πDϵ1​)3/2e−4y2​P(x+y​−ϵv(x),t−ϵ)=[1−ϵ∇⋅v(x)]∫d3y​(4πDϵ1​)3/2e−4Dϵy2​×[P(x,t)+(y​−ϵv(x))⋅∇P+2yi​yj​−2ϵyi​vj​+ϵ2vi​vj​​∇i​∇j​P−ϵ∂t∂P​+O(ϵ2)]=[1−ϵ∇⋅v(x)][P−ϵv⋅∇+ϵD∇2P−ϵ∂t∂P​+O(ϵ2)].​(9.20)​

Equating terms at order of ϵ\epsilonϵ leads to the Fokker-Planck equation,

∂P∂t+∇⋅J⃗=0, with J⃗=v⃗P−D∇P\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \mathcal{P}}{\partial t}+\nabla \cdot \vec{J}=0, \quad \text { with } \quad \vec{J}=\vec{v} \mathcal{P}-D \nabla \mathcal{P} \tag{9.21} \end{equation*}∂t∂P​+∇⋅J=0, with J=vP−D∇P​(9.21)​

The Fokker-Planck equation is simply the statement of conservation of probability. The probability current has a deterministic component v⃗P\vec{v} \mathcal{P}vP, and a stochastic part −D∇P-D \nabla \mathcal{P}−D∇P. A stationary distribution, ∂P/∂t=0\partial \mathcal{P} / \partial t=0∂P/∂t=0, is obtained if the net current vanishes. It is now easy to check that the Boltzmann weight, Peq. (x⃗)∝exp⁡[−V(x⃗)/kBT]\mathcal{P}_{\text {eq. }}(\vec{x}) \propto \exp \left[-\mathcal{V}(\vec{x}) / k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right]Peq. ​(x)∝exp[−V(x)/kB​T], with ∇Peq. =v⃗Peq. /(μkBT)\nabla \mathcal{P}_{\text {eq. }}=\vec{v} \mathcal{P}_{\text {eq. }} /\left(\mu k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)∇Peq. ​=vPeq. ​/(μkB​T), leads to a stationary state as long as the fluctuation-dissipation condition in Eq. (9.12) is satisfied.

9.2 Equilibrium dynamics of a field

The next step is to generalize the Langevin formalism to a collection of degrees of freedom, most conveniently described by a continuous field. Let us consider the order parameter field m⃗(x,t)\vec{m}(\mathbf{x}, t)m(x,t) of a magnet. In equilibrium, the probability to find a coarse-grained configuration of the magnetization field is governed by the Boltzmann weight of the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian

H[m⃗]=∫ddx[r2m2+um4+K2(∇m)2+⋯ ].\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}[\vec{m}]=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{r}{2} m^{2}+u m^{4}+\frac{K}{2}(\nabla m)^{2}+\cdots\right] . \tag{9.22} \end{equation*}H[m]=∫ddx[2r​m2+um4+2K​(∇m)2+⋯].​(9.22)​

(To avoid confusion with time, the coefficient of the quadratic term is changed from ttt to rrr.) Clearly the above energy functional contains no kinetic terms, and should be regarded as the analog of the potential energy V(x⃗)\mathcal{V}(\vec{x})V(x) employed in the previous section. To construct a Langevin equation governing the dynamics of the field m⃗(x)\vec{m}(\mathbf{x})m(x), we first calculate the analogous force on each field element from the variations of this potential energy. The functional derivative of Eq. (9.22) yields

Fi(x)=−δH[m⃗]δmi(x)=−rmi−4umi∣m⃗∣2+K∇2mi\begin{equation*} F_{i}(\mathbf{x})=-\frac{\delta \mathcal{H}[\vec{m}]}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})}=-r m_{i}-4 u m_{i}|\vec{m}|^{2}+K \nabla^{2} m_{i} \tag{9.23} \end{equation*}Fi​(x)=−δmi​(x)δH[m]​=−rmi​−4umi​∣m∣2+K∇2mi​​(9.23)​

The straightforward analog of Eq. (9.2) is

∂mi(x,t)∂t=μFi(x)+ηi(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial m_{i}(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\mu F_{i}(\mathbf{x})+\eta_{i}(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.24} \end{equation*}∂t∂mi​(x,t)​=μFi​(x)+ηi​(x,t)​(9.24)​

with a random "velocity", η⃗\vec{\eta}η​, such that

⟨ηi(x,t)⟩=0, and ⟨ηi(x,t)ηj(x′,t′)⟩=2Dδijδ(x−x′)δ(t−t′).\begin{equation*} \left\langle\eta_{i}(\mathbf{x}, t)\right\rangle=0, \quad \text { and } \quad\left\langle\eta_{i}(\mathbf{x}, t) \eta_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=2 D \delta_{i j} \delta\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) . \tag{9.25} \end{equation*}⟨ηi​(x,t)⟩=0, and ⟨ηi​(x,t)ηj​(x′,t′)⟩=2Dδij​δ(x−x′)δ(t−t′).​(9.25)​

The resulting Langevin equation,

∂m⃗(x,t)∂t=−μrm⃗−4μum2m⃗+μK∇2m⃗+η⃗(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \vec{m}(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=-\mu r \vec{m}-4 \mu u m^{2} \vec{m}+\mu K \nabla^{2} \vec{m}+\vec{\eta}(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.26} \end{equation*}∂t∂m(x,t)​=−μrm−4μum2m+μK∇2m+η​(x,t)​(9.26)​

is known as the time-dependent Landau-Ginzburg equation. Because of the nonlinear term m2m⃗m^{2} \vec{m}m2m, it is not possible to integrate this equation exactly. To gain some insight into its behavior we start with the disordered phase of the model which is well described by the Gaussian weight with u=0u=0u=0. The resulting linear equation is then easily solved by examining the Fourier components,

m⃗(q,t)=∫ddxeiq⋅xm⃗(x,t),\begin{equation*} \vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}} \vec{m}(\mathbf{x}, t), \tag{9.27} \end{equation*}m(q,t)=∫ddxeiq⋅xm(x,t),​(9.27)​

which evolve according to

∂m⃗(q,t)∂t=−μ(r+Kq2)m⃗(q,t)+η⃗(q,t).\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)}{\partial t}=-\mu\left(r+K q^{2}\right) \vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)+\vec{\eta}(\mathbf{q}, t) . \tag{9.28} \end{equation*}∂t∂m(q,t)​=−μ(r+Kq2)m(q,t)+η​(q,t).​(9.28)​

The Fourier transformed noise,

η⃗(q,t)=∫ddxeiqq:η⃗(x,t),\begin{equation*} \vec{\eta}(\mathbf{q}, t)=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q \mathbf{q}: \vec{\eta}}(\mathbf{x}, t), \tag{9.29} \end{equation*}η​(q,t)=∫ddxeiqq:η​(x,t),​(9.29)​

has zero mean, ⟨ηi(q,t)⟩=0\left\langle\eta_{i}(\mathbf{q}, t)\right\rangle=0⟨ηi​(q,t)⟩=0, and correlations

⟨ηi(q,t)ηj(q′,t′)⟩=∫ddx ddx′eiq⋅x+iq′⋅x′⟨ηi(x,t)ηj(x′,t′)⟩⏞2Dδijddx−x′)δ(t−t′)=2Dδijδ(t−t′)∫ddxeix⋅(q+q′)=2Dδijδ(t−t′)(2π)dδd(q+q′).\begin{align*} \left\langle\eta_{i}(\mathbf{q}, t) \eta_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle & =\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}+i \mathbf{q}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{x}^{\prime}} \overbrace{\left\langle\eta_{i}(\mathbf{x}, t) \eta_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle}^{\left.2 D \delta_{i j} d^{d} \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right)} \\ & =2 D \delta_{i j} \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \mathbf{x} \cdot\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)} \tag{9.30}\\ & =2 D \delta_{i j} \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right)(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) . \end{align*}⟨ηi​(q,t)ηj​(q′,t′)⟩​=∫ddx ddx′eiq⋅x+iq′⋅x′⟨ηi​(x,t)ηj​(x′,t′)⟩​2Dδij​ddx−x′)δ(t−t′)​=2Dδij​δ(t−t′)∫ddxeix⋅(q+q′)=2Dδij​δ(t−t′)(2π)dδd(q+q′).​(9.30)​

Each Fourier mode in Eq. (9.28) now behaves as an independent particle connected to a spring as in Eq. (9.6). Introducing a decay rate

γ(q)≡1τ(q)=μ(r+Kq2)\begin{equation*} \gamma(\mathbf{q}) \equiv \frac{1}{\tau(\mathbf{q})}=\mu\left(r+K q^{2}\right) \tag{9.31} \end{equation*}γ(q)≡τ(q)1​=μ(r+Kq2)​(9.31)​

the evolution of each mode is similar to Eq. (9.8), and follows

m⃗(q,t)=m⃗(q,0)e−γ(q)t+∫0t dτe−γ(q)(t−τ)η⃗(q,t).\begin{equation*} \vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)=\vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, 0) \mathrm{e}^{-\gamma(\mathbf{q}) t}+\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{e}^{-\gamma(\mathbf{q})(t-\tau)} \vec{\eta}(\mathbf{q}, t) . \tag{9.32} \end{equation*}m(q,t)=m(q,0)e−γ(q)t+∫0t​ dτe−γ(q)(t−τ)η​(q,t).​(9.32)​

Fluctuations in each mode decay with a different relaxation time τ(q)\tau(\mathbf{q})τ(q); ⟨m⃗(q,t)⟩=m⃗(q,0)exp⁡[−t/τ(q)]\langle\vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)\rangle=\vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, 0) \exp [-t / \tau(\mathbf{q})]⟨m(q,t)⟩=m(q,0)exp[−t/τ(q)]. When in equilibrium, the order parameter in the Gaussain model is correlated over the length scale ξ=K/r\xi=\sqrt{K / r}ξ=K/r​. In considering relaxation to equilibrium, we find that at length scales larger than ξ\xiξ (or q≪1/ξq \ll 1 / \xiq≪1/ξ ), the relaxation time saturates to τmax⁡=1/(μr)\tau_{\max }=1 /(\mu r)τmax​=1/(μr). On approaching the singular point of the Gaussian model at r=0r=0r=0, the time required to reach equilibrium diverges. This phenomenon is known as critical slowing down, and is also present for the nonlinear equation, albeit with modified exponents. The critical point is thus characterized by diverging length and time scales. For the critical fluctuations at distances shorter than the correlation length ξ\xiξ, the characteristic time scale grows with wavelength as τ(q)≈(μKq2)−1\tau(q) \approx\left(\mu K q^{2}\right)^{-1}τ(q)≈(μKq2)−1. The scaling relation between the critical length and time scales is described by a dynamic exponent zzz, as τ∝λz\tau \propto \lambda^{z}τ∝λz. The value of z=2z=2z=2 for the critical Gaussian model is reminiscent of diffusion processes.

Time-dependent correlation functions are obtained from

⟨mi(q,t)mj(q′,t)⟩c=∫0t dτ1 dτ2e−γ(q)(t−τ1)−γ(q′)(t−τ2)⟨ηi(q,τ1)ηj(q′,τ2)⟩2Dδijδ(τ1−τ2)(2π)dδd(q+q′)=(2π)dδd(q+q′)2Dδij∫0t dτe−2γ(q)(t−τ)=(2π)dδd(q+q′)δijDγ(q)(1−e−2γ(q)t)→t→∞(2π)dδd(q+q′)δijDμ(r+Kq2).\begin{align*} \left\langle m_{i}(\mathbf{q}, t) m_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}, t\right)\right\rangle_{c}= & \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau_{1} \mathrm{~d} \tau_{2} \mathrm{e}^{-\gamma(\mathbf{q})\left(t-\tau_{1}\right)-\gamma\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\left(t-\tau_{2}\right)} \stackrel{2 D \delta_{i j} \delta\left(\tau_{1}-\tau_{2}\right)(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}{\left\langle\eta_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}, \tau_{1}\right) \eta_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}, \tau_{2}\right)\right\rangle} \\ = & (2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) 2 D \delta_{i j} \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{e}^{-2 \gamma(\mathbf{q})(t-\tau)} \tag{9.33}\\ = & (2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) \delta_{i j} \frac{D}{\gamma(\mathbf{q})}\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 \gamma(\mathbf{q}) t}\right) \\ & \xrightarrow{t \rightarrow \infty}(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) \delta_{i j} \frac{D}{\mu\left(r+K q^{2}\right)} . \end{align*}⟨mi​(q,t)mj​(q′,t)⟩c​===​∫0t​ dτ1​ dτ2​e−γ(q)(t−τ1​)−γ(q′)(t−τ2​)⟨ηi​(q,τ1​)ηj​(q′,τ2​)⟩2Dδij​δ(τ1​−τ2​)(2π)dδd(q+q′)​(2π)dδd(q+q′)2Dδij​∫0t​ dτe−2γ(q)(t−τ)(2π)dδd(q+q′)δij​γ(q)D​(1−e−2γ(q)t)t→∞​(2π)dδd(q+q′)δij​μ(r+Kq2)D​.​(9.33)​

However, direct diagonalization of the Hamiltonian in Eq. (9.22) with u=0u=0u=0 gives

H=∫ddq(2π)d(r+Kq2)2∣m⃗(q)∣2,\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{\left(r+K q^{2}\right)}{2}|\vec{m}(\mathbf{q})|^{2}, \tag{9.34} \end{equation*}H=∫(2π)dddq​2(r+Kq2)​∣m(q)∣2,​(9.34)​

leading to the equilibrium correlation functions

⟨mi(q)mj(q′)⟩=(2π)dδd(q+q′)δijkBTr+Kq2\begin{equation*} \left\langle m_{i}(\mathbf{q}) m_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) \delta_{i j} \frac{k_{\mathrm{B}} T}{r+K q^{2}} \tag{9.35} \end{equation*}⟨mi​(q)mj​(q′)⟩=(2π)dδd(q+q′)δij​r+Kq2kB​T​​(9.35)​

Comparing Eqs. (9.33) and (9.35) indicates that the long-time dynamics reproduce the correct equilibrium behavior if the fluctuation-dissipation condition, D=kBTμD=k_{\mathrm{B}} T \muD=kB​Tμ, is satisfied.

In fact, quite generally, the single-particle Fokker-Planck equation (9.21) can be generalized to describe the evolution of the whole probability functional, P([m⃗(x)],t)\mathcal{P}([\vec{m}(\mathbf{x})], t)P([m(x)],t), as

∂P([m⃗(x)],t)∂t=−∫ddxδδmi(x)[−μδHδmi(x)P−DδPδmi(x)]\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \mathcal{P}([\vec{m}(\mathbf{x})], t)}{\partial t}=-\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \frac{\delta}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})}\left[-\mu \frac{\delta \mathcal{H}}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})} \mathcal{P}-D \frac{\delta \mathcal{P}}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})}\right] \tag{9.36} \end{equation*}∂t∂P([m(x)],t)​=−∫ddxδmi​(x)δ​[−μδmi​(x)δH​P−Dδmi​(x)δP​]​(9.36)​

For the equilibrium Boltzmann weight

Peq [m⃗(x)]∝exp⁡[−H[m⃗(x)]kBT],\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}_{\text {eq }}[\vec{m}(\mathbf{x})] \propto \exp \left[-\frac{\mathcal{H}[\vec{m}(\mathbf{x})]}{k_{B} T}\right], \tag{9.37} \end{equation*}Peq ​[m(x)]∝exp[−kB​TH[m(x)]​],​(9.37)​

the functional derivative results in

δPeq. δmi(x)=−1kBTδHδmi(x)Peq. .\begin{equation*} \frac{\delta \mathcal{P}_{\text {eq. }}}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})}=-\frac{1}{k_{B} T} \frac{\delta \mathcal{H}}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})} \mathcal{P}_{\text {eq. }} . \tag{9.38} \end{equation*}δmi​(x)δPeq. ​​=−kB​T1​δmi​(x)δH​Peq. ​.​(9.38)​

The total probability current,

J[h(x)]=[−μδHδmi(x)+DkBTδHδmi(x)]Peq,\begin{equation*} J[h(\mathbf{x})]=\left[-\mu \frac{\delta \mathcal{H}}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})}+\frac{D}{k_{B} T} \frac{\delta \mathcal{H}}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})}\right] \mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{eq}}, \tag{9.39} \end{equation*}J[h(x)]=[−μδmi​(x)δH​+kB​TD​δmi​(x)δH​]Peq​,​(9.39)​

vanishes if the fluctuation-dissipation condition, D=μkBTD=\mu k_{\mathrm{B}} TD=μkB​T, is satisfied. Once again, the Einstein equation ensures that the equilibrium weight indeed describes a steady state.

9.3 Dynamics of a conserved field

In fact it is possible to obtain the correct equilibrium weight with q\mathbf{q}q dependent mobility and noise, as long as the generalized fluctuation-dissipation condition,

D(q)=kBTμ(q),\begin{equation*} D(\mathbf{q})=k_{\mathrm{B}} T \mu(\mathbf{q}), \tag{9.40} \end{equation*}D(q)=kB​Tμ(q),​(9.40)​

holds. This generalized condition is useful in considering the dissipative dynamics of a conserved field. The prescription that leads to the Langevin equations (9.23)-(9.25) does not conserve the field in the sense that ∫ddxm⃗(x,t)\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \vec{m}(\mathbf{x}, t)∫ddxm(x,t) can change with time. (Although this quantity is on average zero for r>0r>0r>0, it undergoes stochastic fluctuations.) If we are dealing with a binary mixture (n=1)(n=1)(n=1), the order parameter which measures the difference between densities of the two components is conserved. Any concentration that is removed from some part of the system must go to a neighboring region in any realistic dynamics. Let us then consider a local dynamical process constrained such that

d dt∫ ddxm⃗(x,t)=∫ddx∂m⃗(x,t)∂t=0→\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \vec{m}(\mathbf{x}, t)=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \frac{\partial \vec{m}(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\overrightarrow{0} \tag{9.41} \end{equation*} dtd​∫ ddxm(x,t)=∫ddx∂t∂m(x,t)​=0​(9.41)​

How can we construct a dynamical equation that satisfies Eq. (9.41)? The integral clearly vanishes if the integrand is a total divergence, i.e.

∂mi(x,t)∂t=−∇⋅ji+ηi(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial m_{i}(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=-\nabla \cdot \mathbf{j}_{i}+\eta_{i}(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.42} \end{equation*}∂t∂mi​(x,t)​=−∇⋅ji​+ηi​(x,t)​(9.42)​

The noise itself must be a total divergence, ηi=−∇⋅σi\eta_{i}=-\nabla \cdot \sigma_{i}ηi​=−∇⋅σi​, and hence in Fourier space,

⟨ηi(q,t)⟩=0, and ⟨ηi(q,t)ηj(q′,t′)⟩=2Dδijq2δ(t−t′)(2π)dδd(q+q′)\begin{equation*} \left\langle\eta_{i}(\mathbf{q}, t)\right\rangle=0, \quad \text { and } \quad\left\langle\eta_{i}(\mathbf{q}, t) \eta_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=2 D \delta_{i j} q^{2} \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right)(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) \tag{9.43} \end{equation*}⟨ηi​(q,t)⟩=0, and ⟨ηi​(q,t)ηj​(q′,t′)⟩=2Dδij​q2δ(t−t′)(2π)dδd(q+q′)​(9.43)​

We can now take advantage of the generalized Einstein relation in Eq. (9.40) to ensure the correct equilibrium distribution by setting,

ji=μ∇⋅(−δHδmi(x)).\begin{equation*} \mathbf{j}_{i}=\mu \nabla \cdot\left(-\frac{\delta \mathcal{H}}{\delta m_{i}(\mathbf{x})}\right) . \tag{9.44} \end{equation*}ji​=μ∇⋅(−δmi​(x)δH​).​(9.44)​

The standard terminology for such dynamical equations is provided by Hohenberg and Halperin [P.C. Hohenberg and B.I. Halperin, Rev. Mod. Phys. 49, 435 (1977)]. In model A dynamics the field m⃗\vec{m}m is not conserved, and the mobility and diffusion coefficients are constants. In model B dynamics the field m⃗\vec{m}m is conserved, and μ^=−μ∇2\widehat{\mu}=-\mu \nabla^{2}μ​=−μ∇2 and D^=−D∇2\widehat{D}=-D \nabla^{2}D=−D∇2.

Let us now reconsider the Gaussian model (u=0)(u=0)(u=0), this time with a conserved order parameter, with model B dynamics

∂m⃗(x,t)∂t=μr∇2m⃗−μK∇4m⃗+η⃗(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \vec{m}(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\mu r \nabla^{2} \vec{m}-\mu K \nabla^{4} \vec{m}+\vec{\eta}(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.45} \end{equation*}∂t∂m(x,t)​=μr∇2m−μK∇4m+η​(x,t)​(9.45)​

The evolution of each Fourier mode is given by

∂m⃗(q,t)∂t=−μq2(r+Kq2)m⃗(q,t)+η⃗(q,t)≡−m⃗(q,t)τ(q)+η⃗(q,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)}{\partial t}=-\mu q^{2}\left(r+K q^{2}\right) \vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)+\vec{\eta}(\mathbf{q}, t) \equiv-\frac{\vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)}{\tau(\mathbf{q})}+\vec{\eta}(\mathbf{q}, t) \tag{9.46} \end{equation*}∂t∂m(q,t)​=−μq2(r+Kq2)m(q,t)+η​(q,t)≡−τ(q)m(q,t)​+η​(q,t)​(9.46)​

Because of the constraints imposed by the conservation law, the relaxation of the field is more difficult, and slower. The relaxation times diverge even away from criticality. Depending on wavelength, we find scaling between length and time scales with dynamic exponents zzz, according to

τ(q)=1μq2(r+Kq2)≈{q−2 for q≪ξ−1(z=2)q−4 for q≫ξ−1(z=4)(9.47)\tau(\mathbf{q})=\frac{1}{\mu q^{2}\left(r+K q^{2}\right)} \approx\left\{\begin{array}{lll} q^{-2} & \text { for } q \ll \xi^{-1} & (z=2) \tag{9.47}\\ q^{-4} & \text { for } q \gg \xi^{-1} & (z=4) \end{array}\right.τ(q)=μq2(r+Kq2)1​≈{q−2q−4​ for q≪ξ−1 for q≫ξ−1​(z=2)(z=4)​(9.47)

The equilibrium behavior is unchanged, and

lim⁡t→∞⟨∣m⃗(q,t)∣2⟩=nDq2μq2(r+Kq2)=nDμ(r+Kq2)\begin{equation*} \left.\left.\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty}\langle | \vec{m}(\mathbf{q}, t)\right|^{2}\right\rangle=n \frac{D q^{2}}{\mu q^{2}\left(r+K q^{2}\right)}=\frac{n D}{\mu\left(r+K q^{2}\right)} \tag{9.48} \end{equation*}t→∞lim​⟨∣m(q,t)​2⟩=nμq2(r+Kq2)Dq2​=μ(r+Kq2)nD​​(9.48)​

as before. Thus the same static behavior can be achieved by different dynamics. The static exponents (e.g. ν\nuν ) are determined by the equilibrium (stationary) state and are unchanged, while the dynamic exponents may be different. As a result, dynamical critical phenomena involve more universality classes than the corresponding static ones. We shall not elaborate on dynamic critical phenomena any further. In addition to the standard review article by Hohenberg and Halperin [P.C. Hohenberg and B.I. Halperin, Rev. Mod. Phys. 49, 435 (1977)], more details can be found in references [S.-K. Ma, Modern Theory of Critical Phenomena (Benjamin-Cummings, Reading, MA, 1976)] and [D. Forster, Hydrodynamic Fluctuations, Broken Symmetries, and Correlation Functions (Benjamin-Cummings, Reading, MA, 1975)].

9.4 Generic scale invariance in equilibrium systems

We live in a world full of complex spatial patterns and structures such as coastlines and river networks. There are similarly diverse temporal processes generically exhibiting " 1/f1 / f1/f " noise, as in resistance fluctuations, sand flowing through an hour glass, and even in traffic and stock market movements. These phenomena lack natural length and time scales and exhibit scale invariance and self-similarity. The spacial aspects of scale invariant systems can be characterized using fractal geometry [B.B. Mandelbrot, The Fractal Geometry of Nature (Freeman, San Francisco, 1982)]. In this section we explore dynamical processes that can naturally result in such scale invariant patterns.

Let us assume that the system of interest is described by a scalar field m(x)m(\mathbf{x})m(x), distributed with a probability P[m]\mathcal{P}[m]P[m]. Scale invariance can be probed by examining the correlation functions of m(x)m(\mathbf{x})m(x), such as the two point correlator, C(∣x−y∣)≡⟨m(x)m(y)⟩−⟨m(x)⟩⟨m(y)⟩C(|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}|) \equiv\langle m(\mathbf{x}) m(\mathbf{y})\rangle-\langle m(\mathbf{x})\rangle\langle m(\mathbf{y})\rangleC(∣x−y∣)≡⟨m(x)m(y)⟩−⟨m(x)⟩⟨m(y)⟩. (It is assumed that the system has rotational and translational symmetry.) In a system with a characteristic length scale, correlations decay to zero for separations z=∣x−y∣≫ξz=|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}| \gg \xiz=∣x−y∣≫ξ. By contrast, if the system possesses scale invariance, correlations are homogeneous at long distances, and lim⁡z→∞C(z)∼z2χ\lim _{z \rightarrow \infty} C(z) \sim z^{2 \chi}limz→∞​C(z)∼z2χ.

As we have seen, in equilibrium statistical mechanics the probability is given by Peq ∝exp⁡(−βH[m])\mathcal{P}_{\text {eq }} \propto \exp (-\beta \mathcal{H}[m])Peq ​∝exp(−βH[m]) with β=(kBT)−1\beta=\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)^{-1}β=(kB​T)−1. Clearly at infinite temperature there are no correlations for a finite Hamiltonian. As long as the interactions in H[m]\mathcal{H}[m]H[m] are short ranged, it can be shown by high temperature expansions that correlations at small but finite β\betaβ decay as C(z)∝exp⁡(−z/ξ)C(z) \propto \exp (-z / \xi)C(z)∝exp(−z/ξ), indicating a characteristic length scale 1{ }^{1}1. The correlation length usually increases upon reducing temperature, and may diverge if the system undergoes a continuous (critical) phase transition. At a critical transition the system is scale invariant and C(z)∝z2−d−ηC(z) \propto z^{2-d-\eta}C(z)∝z2−d−η. However, such scale invariance is non-generic in the sense that it can be obtained only by precise tuning of the system to the critical temperature. Most scale invariant processes in nature do not require such

[^7]precise tuning, and therefore the analogy to the critical point is not particularly instructive [T. Hwa and M. Kardar, Phys. Rev. A 45, 7002 (1992). Similar motivations underlie the development of the concept of self-organized criticality by P. Bak, C. Tang and K. Wiesenfeld, Phys. Rev. Lett. 59, 381 (1987). The distinctions and similarities to generic scale invariance are discussed in Ref. [T. Hwa and M. Kardar, Phys. Rev. A 45, 7002 (1992)].

We shall frame our discussion of scale invariance by considering the dynamics of a surface, described by its height h(x,t)h(\mathbf{x}, t)h(x,t). Specific examples are the distortions of a soap film or the fluctuations on the surface of water in a container. In both cases the minimum energy configuration is a flat surface (ignoring the small effects of gravity on the soap film). The energy cost of small fluctuations for a soap film comes from the increased area and surface tension σ\sigmaσ. Expanding the area in powers of the slope results in

Hσ=σ∫ddx[1+(∇h)2−1]≈σ2∫ ddx(∇h)2\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}_{\sigma}=\sigma \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\sqrt{1+(\nabla h)^{2}}-1\right] \approx \frac{\sigma}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}(\nabla h)^{2} \tag{9.49} \end{equation*}Hσ​=σ∫ddx[1+(∇h)2​−1]≈2σ​∫ ddx(∇h)2​(9.49)​

For the surface of water there is an additional gravitational potential energy, obtained by adding the contributions from all columns of water as

Hg=∫ddx∫0h(x)ρgh(x)=ρg2∫ ddxh(x)2.\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}_{g}=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \int_{0}^{h(\mathbf{x})} \rho g h(\mathbf{x})=\frac{\rho g}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} h(\mathbf{x})^{2} . \tag{9.50} \end{equation*}Hg​=∫ddx∫0h(x)​ρgh(x)=2ρg​∫ ddxh(x)2.​(9.50)​

The total (potential) energy of small fluctuations is thus given by

H=∫ddx[σ2(∇h)2+ρg2h2],\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{\sigma}{2}(\nabla h)^{2}+\frac{\rho g}{2} h^{2}\right], \tag{9.51} \end{equation*}H=∫ddx[2σ​(∇h)2+2ρg​h2],​(9.51)​

with the second term absent for the soap film. The corresponding Langevin equation,

∂h(x,t)∂t=−μρgh+μσ∇2h+η(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial h(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=-\mu \rho g h+\mu \sigma \nabla^{2} h+\eta(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.52} \end{equation*}∂t∂h(x,t)​=−μρgh+μσ∇2h+η(x,t)​(9.52)​

is similar to the linearized version of Eq. (9.26), and can be solved by Fourier transforms. Starting with a flat interface, h(x,t=0)=h(q,t=0)=0h(\mathbf{x}, t=0)=h(\mathbf{q}, t=0)=0h(x,t=0)=h(q,t=0)=0, the profile at time ttt is

h(x,t)=∫ddq(2π)de−iq⋅x∫0t dτe−μ(ρg+σq2)(t−τ)η(q,t)\begin{equation*} h(\mathbf{x}, t)=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \mathbf{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}} \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{e}^{-\mu\left(\rho g+\sigma q^{2}\right)(t-\tau)} \eta(\mathbf{q}, t) \tag{9.53} \end{equation*}h(x,t)=∫(2π)dddq​e−iq⋅x∫0t​ dτe−μ(ρg+σq2)(t−τ)η(q,t)​(9.53)​

The average height of the surface, Hˉ=∫ddx⟨h(x,t)⟩/Ld\bar{H}=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\langle h(\mathbf{x}, t)\rangle / L^{d}Hˉ=∫ddx⟨h(x,t)⟩/Ld, is zero, while its overall width is defined by

w2(t,L)≡1Ld∫ ddx⟨h(x,t)2⟩=1Ld∫ ddq(2π)d⟨∣h(q,t)∣2⟩\begin{equation*} \left.w^{2}(t, L) \equiv \frac{1}{L^{d}} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left\langle h(\mathbf{x}, t)^{2}\right\rangle=\left.\frac{1}{L^{d}} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\langle | h(\mathbf{q}, t)\right|^{2}\right\rangle \tag{9.54} \end{equation*}w2(t,L)≡Ld1​∫ ddx⟨h(x,t)2⟩=Ld1​∫(2π)d ddq​⟨∣h(q,t)​2⟩​(9.54)​

where LLL is the linear size of the surface. Similar to Eq. (9.33), we find that the width grows as

w2(t,L)=∫ddq(2π)dDγ(q)(1−e−2γ(q)t).\begin{equation*} w^{2}(t, L)=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{D}{\gamma(\mathbf{q})}\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 \gamma(\mathbf{q}) t}\right) . \tag{9.55} \end{equation*}w2(t,L)=∫(2π)dddq​γ(q)D​(1−e−2γ(q)t).​(9.55)​

There are a range of time scales in the problem, related to characteristic length scales as in Eq. (9.31). The shortest time scale, tmin⁡∝a2/(μσ)t_{\min } \propto a^{2} /(\mu \sigma)tmin​∝a2/(μσ), is set by an atomic size aaa. The longest time scale is set by either the capillary length (λc≡σ/ρg\left(\lambda_{c} \equiv \sqrt{\sigma / \rho g}\right.(λc​≡σ/ρg​ ) or the system size (L)(L)(L). For simplicity we shall focus on the soap film where the effects of gravity are negligible and tmax⁡∝L2/(μσ)t_{\max } \propto L^{2} /(\mu \sigma)tmax​∝L2/(μσ). We can now identify three different ranges of behavior in Eq. (9.55): (a) For t≪tmin⁡t \ll t_{\min }t≪tmin​, none of the modes has relaxed since γ(q)t≪1\gamma(\mathbf{q}) t \ll 1γ(q)t≪1 for all q\mathbf{q}q. Each mode grows diffusively, and

w2(t,L)=∫ddq(2π)dDγ(q)2γ(q)t=2Dtad.\begin{equation*} w^{2}(t, L)=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{D}{\gamma(\mathbf{q})} 2 \gamma(\mathbf{q}) t=\frac{2 D t}{a^{d}} . \tag{9.56} \end{equation*}w2(t,L)=∫(2π)dddq​γ(q)D​2γ(q)t=ad2Dt​.​(9.56)​

(b) For t≫tmax⁡t \gg t_{\max }t≫tmax​, all modes have relaxed to their equilibrium values since γ(q)t≫1\gamma(\mathbf{q}) t \gg 1γ(q)t≫1 for all q\mathbf{q}q. The height fluctuations now saturate to a maximum value given by

w2(t,L)=∫ddq(2π)dDμσq2.\begin{equation*} w^{2}(t, L)=\int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{D}{\mu \sigma q^{2}} . \tag{9.57} \end{equation*}w2(t,L)=∫(2π)dddq​μσq2D​.​(9.57)​

The saturated value depends on the dimensionality of the surface, and in a general dimension ddd behaves as

w2(t,L)∝Dμσ{a2−d for d>2,(χ=0)ln⁡(L/a) for d=2,(χ=0+)L2−d for d<2,(χ=2−d2)(9.58)w^{2}(t, L) \propto \frac{D}{\mu \sigma}\left\{\begin{array}{lll} a^{2-d} & \text { for } d>2, & (\chi=0) \tag{9.58}\\ \ln (L / a) & \text { for } d=2, & \left(\chi=0^{+}\right) \\ L^{2-d} & \text { for } d<2, & \left(\chi=\frac{2-d}{2}\right) \end{array}\right.w2(t,L)∝μσD​⎩⎨⎧​a2−dln(L/a)L2−d​ for d>2, for d=2, for d<2,​(χ=0)(χ=0+)(χ=22−d​)​(9.58)

where we have defined a roughness exponent χ\chiχ that governs the divergence of the width with system size via lim⁡t→∞w(t,L)∝Lχ\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} w(t, L) \propto L^{\chi}limt→∞​w(t,L)∝Lχ. (The symbol 0+0^{+}0+is used to indicate a logarithmic divergence.) The exponent of χ=1/2\chi=1 / 2χ=1/2 in d=1d=1d=1 indicates that the one dimensional interface fluctuates like a random walk. (c) For tmin⁡≪t≪tmax⁡t_{\min } \ll t \ll t_{\max }tmin​≪t≪tmax​ only a fraction of the shorter length scale modes are saturated. The integrand in Eq. (9.55) (for g=0g=0g=0 ) is made dimensionless by setting y=μσq2ty=\mu \sigma q^{2} ty=μσq2t, and

w2(t,L)∝Dμσ∫ dqqd−3(1−e−2μσq2t)∝Dμσ(1μσt)d−22∫t/tmax⁡t/tmin⁡dyyd−42(1−e−2y)\begin{align*} w^{2}(t, L) & \propto \frac{D}{\mu \sigma} \int \mathrm{~d} q q^{d-3}\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 \mu \sigma q^{2} t}\right) \\ & \propto \frac{D}{\mu \sigma}\left(\frac{1}{\mu \sigma t}\right)^{\frac{d-2}{2}} \int_{t / t_{\max }}^{t / t_{\min }} \mathrm{d} y y^{\frac{d-4}{2}}\left(1-\mathrm{e}^{-2 y}\right) \tag{9.59} \end{align*}w2(t,L)​∝μσD​∫ dqqd−3(1−e−2μσq2t)∝μσD​(μσt1​)2d−2​∫t/tmax​t/tmin​​dyy2d−4​(1−e−2y)​(9.59)​

The final integral is convergent for d<2d<2d<2, and dominated by its upper limit for d≥2d \geq 2d≥2. The initial growth of the width is described by another exponent β\betaβ, defined through lim⁡t→0w(t,L)∝tβ\lim _{t \rightarrow 0} w(t, L) \propto t^{\beta}limt→0​w(t,L)∝tβ, and

w2(t,L)∝{Dμσa2−d for d>2,(β=0)Dμσln⁡(t/tmin⁡) for d=2,(β=0+)D(μσ)d/2t(2−d)/2 for d<2,(β=(2−d)/4)(9.60)w^{2}(t, L) \propto\left\{\begin{array}{lll} \frac{D}{\mu \sigma} a^{2-d} & \text { for } d>2, & (\beta=0) \tag{9.60}\\ \frac{D}{\mu \sigma} \ln \left(t / t_{\min }\right) & \text { for } d=2, & \left(\beta=0^{+}\right) \\ \frac{D}{(\mu \sigma)^{d / 2}} t^{(2-d) / 2} & \text { for } d<2, & (\beta=(2-d) / 4) \end{array}\right.w2(t,L)∝⎩⎨⎧​μσD​a2−dμσD​ln(t/tmin​)(μσ)d/2D​t(2−d)/2​ for d>2, for d=2, for d<2,​(β=0)(β=0+)(β=(2−d)/4)​(9.60)

The exponents χ\chiχ and β\betaβ also describe the height-height correlation functions which assumes the dynamic scaling form

⟨[h(x,t)−h(x′,t′)]2⟩=∣x−x′∣2χg(∣t−t′∣∣x−x′∣z).\begin{equation*} \left\langle\left[h(\mathbf{x}, t)-h\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right]^{2}\right\rangle=\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{2 \chi} g\left(\frac{\left|t-t^{\prime}\right|}{\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{z}}\right) . \tag{9.61} \end{equation*}⟨[h(x,t)−h(x′,t′)]2⟩=∣x−x′∣2χg(∣x−x′∣z∣t−t′∣​).​(9.61)​

Since equilibrium equal time correlations only depend on ∣x−x′∣,lim⁡y→0g(y)\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|, \lim _{y \rightarrow 0} g(y)∣x−x′∣,limy→0​g(y) should be a constant. On the other hand, correlations at the same point can only depend on time, requiring that lim⁡y→∞g(y)∝y2χ/z\lim _{y \rightarrow \infty} g(y) \propto y^{2 \chi / z}limy→∞​g(y)∝y2χ/z, and leading to the exponent identity β=χ/z\beta=\chi / zβ=χ/z.

This scale invariance is broken when the gravitational potential energy is added to the Hamiltonian. The correlations now decay as C(z)∝exp⁡(−z/λc)C(z) \propto \exp \left(-z / \lambda_{c}\right)C(z)∝exp(−z/λc​) for distances larger than the capillary length. What is the underlying difference between these two cases? The presence of gravity breaks the translational symmetry, H[h(x)+c]=H[h(x)]\mathcal{H}[h(\mathbf{x})+c]=\mathcal{H}[h(\mathbf{x})]H[h(x)+c]=H[h(x)]. It is this continuous symmetry that forbids the occurrence of a term proportional to ∫ddxh(x)2\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} h(\mathbf{x})^{2}∫ddxh(x)2 in the Hamiltonian and removes the corresponding length scale. (The coefficient of the quadratic term is usually referred to as a mass in field theoretical language.) The presence of a continuous symmetry is quite a general condition for obtaining generic scale invariance (GSI) [G. Grinstein, S. Sachdev, and D.H. Lee, Phys. Rev. Lett. 64, 1927 (1990)]. As discussed in previous chapters, there are many low temperature phases of matter in which a continuous symmetry is spontaneously broken. The energy cost of small fluctuations around such a state must obey the global symmetry. The resulting excitations are the "massless" Goldstone modes. We already discussed such modes in connection with magnons in ferromagnets (with broken rotational symmetry), and phonons in solids (broken translational symmetry). All these cases exhibit scale invariant fluctuations.

In the realm of dynamics we can ask the more general question of whether temporal correlations, e.g. C(∣x−x′∣,t−t′)=⟨h(x,t)h(x′,t′)⟩cC\left(\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|, t-t^{\prime}\right)=\left\langle h(\mathbf{x}, t) h\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{c}C(∣x−x′∣,t−t′)=⟨h(x,t)h(x′,t′)⟩c​, exhibit a characteristic time scale τ\tauτ, or are homogeneous in t−t′t-t^{\prime}t−t′. It is natural to expect that scale invariance in the spacial and temporal domains are closely interlinked. Establishing correlations at large distances requires long times as long as the system follows local dynamical rules (typically (t−t′)∝∣x−x′∣z\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) \propto\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{z}(t−t′)∝∣x−x′∣z ). Spacial scale invariance thus implies the lack of a time scale. The converse is not true as dynamics provides an additional possibility of removing time scales through a conservation law. We will, for example, encounter this situation in examining the model B dynamics of the surface Hamiltonian in the presence of gravity. Equation (9.47) indicates that, even though the long wavelength modes are massive, the relaxation time of a mode of wavenumber q\mathbf{q}q diverges as 1/q21 / q^{2}1/q2 in the q→0\mathbf{q} \rightarrow \mathbf{0}q→0 limit.

Symmetries and conservation laws are intimately linked in equilibrium systems. Consider a local Hamiltonian that is invariant under the symmetry H[h(x)+c]=H[h(x)]\mathcal{H}[h(\mathbf{x})+c]=\mathcal{H}[h(\mathbf{x})]H[h(x)+c]=H[h(x)]. Since H\mathcal{H}H can only depend on ∇h\nabla h∇h and higher derivatives,

v=μF=−μδHδh(x)=μ∇⋅∂H∂∇h+⋯≡∇⋅j⃗\begin{equation*} v=\mu F=-\mu \frac{\delta \mathcal{H}}{\delta h(\mathbf{x})}=\mu \nabla \cdot \frac{\partial \mathcal{H}}{\partial \nabla h}+\cdots \equiv \nabla \cdot \vec{j} \tag{9.62} \end{equation*}v=μF=−μδh(x)δH​=μ∇⋅∂∇h∂H​+⋯≡∇⋅j​​(9.62)​

Even for model A dynamics, the deterministic part of the velocity is the divergence of a current and conserves ∫ddxh(x,t)\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} h(\mathbf{x}, t)∫ddxh(x,t). The conservation is only statistical and locally broken by the non-conserved noise in model A. The above result is a consequence of Noether's theorem.

9.5 Non-equilibrium dynamics of open systems

We have to be cautious in applying the methods and lessons of near equilibrium dynamics to the various processes in nature which exhibit generic scale invariance. Many such systems, such as a flowing river or a drifting cloud, are very far from equilibrium. Furthermore, they are open and extended systems constantly exchanging particles and constituents with their environment. It is not clear that there is any simple Hamiltonian that governs the dynamics of such processes and hence the traditional approach presented earlier is not necessarily appropriate. However, the robust self-similar correlations observed in these systems [B.B. Mandelbrot, The Fractal Geometry of Nature (Freeman, San Francisco, 1982)] suggests that they can be described by stationary scale invariant probability distributions. This section outlines a general approach to the dynamics of open and extended systems that is similar in spirit to the construction of effective coarse-grained field theories described in chapter 2. Let us again consider the dynamics of a static field, h(x,t)h(\mathbf{x}, t)h(x,t) : (1) The starting point in equilibrium statistical mechanics is the Hamiltonian H[h]\mathcal{H}[h]H[h]. Landau's prescription is to include in H\mathcal{H}H all terms consistent with the symmetries of the problem. The underlying philosophy is that in a generic situation an allowed term is present, and can only vanish by accident. In the case of non-equilibrium dynamics we shall assume that the equation of motion is the fundamental object of interest. Over sufficiently long time scales, inertial terms (∝∂t2h)\left(\propto \partial_{t}^{2} h\right)(∝∂t2​h) are irrelevant in the presence of dissipative dynamics, and the evolution of hhh is governed by

∂th(x,t)=v[h(x,t)]⏞deterministic +η(x,t)⏞stochastic .\begin{equation*} \partial_{t} h(\mathbf{x}, t)=\overbrace{v[h(\mathbf{x}, t)]}^{\text {deterministic }}+\overbrace{\eta(\mathbf{x}, t)}^{\text {stochastic }} . \tag{9.63} \end{equation*}∂t​h(x,t)=v[h(x,t)]​deterministic ​+η(x,t)​stochastic ​.​(9.63)​

(2) If the interactions are short ranged, the velocity at ( x,t)\mathbf{x}, t)x,t) depends only on h(x,t)h(\mathbf{x}, t)h(x,t) and a few derivatives evaluated at (x,t)(\mathbf{x}, t)(x,t), i.e.

v(x,t)=v(h(x,t),∇h(x,t),⋯ )\begin{equation*} v(\mathbf{x}, t)=v(h(\mathbf{x}, t), \nabla h(\mathbf{x}, t), \cdots) \tag{9.64} \end{equation*}v(x,t)=v(h(x,t),∇h(x,t),⋯)​(9.64)​

(3) We must next specify the functional form of deterministic velocity, and the correlations in noise. Generalizing Landau's prescription, we assume that all terms consistent with the underlying symmetries and conservation laws will generically appear in vvv. The noise, η(x,t)\eta(\mathbf{x}, t)η(x,t), may be conservative or non-conservative depending on whether there are only internal rearrangements, or external inputs and outputs.

Corollary: Note that with these set of rules there is no reason for the velocity to be derivable from a potential (v≠−μ^δH/δh)(v \neq-\widehat{\mu} \delta \mathcal{H} / \delta h)(v=−μ​δH/δh), and there is no fluctuationdissipation condition (D^≠μ^kBT)\left(\widehat{D} \neq \widehat{\mu} k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)(D=μ​kB​T). It is even possible for the deterministic velocity to be conservative, while the noise is not. Thus various familiar results of near equilibrium dynamics may no longer hold.

As an example consider the flow of water along a river (or traffic along a highway). The deterministic part of the dynamics is conservative (the amount of water, or the number of cars is unchanged). Hence the velocity is the divergence of a current, v=−∇j⃗[h]v=-\nabla \vec{j}[h]v=−∇j​[h]. The current, j⃗\vec{j}j​, is a vector, and must be constructed out of the other two vectorial quantities in the problem: the gradient operator ∇\nabla∇, and the average transport direction t^\widehat{t}t. (The unit vector t^\widehat{t}t points along the direction of current or traffic flow.) The lowest order terms in the expansion of the current give

−j⃗=t^(αh−λ2h2+⋯ )+ν1∇h+ν2t^(t^⋅∇)h+⋯\begin{equation*} -\vec{j}=\widehat{t}\left(\alpha h-\frac{\lambda}{2} h^{2}+\cdots\right)+\nu_{1} \nabla h+\nu_{2} \widehat{t}(\widehat{t} \cdot \nabla) h+\cdots \tag{9.65} \end{equation*}−j​=t(αh−2λ​h2+⋯)+ν1​∇h+ν2​t(t⋅∇)h+⋯​(9.65)​

The components of current parallel and perpendicular to the net flow are

{−j∥=αh−λ2h2+(ν1+ν2)∂∥h+⋯−j⃗⊥=ν1∂⃗⊥h+⋯(9.66)\left\{\begin{array}{l} -j_{\|}=\alpha h-\frac{\lambda}{2} h^{2}+\left(\nu_{1}+\nu_{2}\right) \partial_{\|} h+\cdots \tag{9.66}\\ -\vec{j}_{\perp}=\nu_{1} \vec{\partial}_{\perp} h+\cdots \end{array}\right.{−j∥​=αh−2λ​h2+(ν1​+ν2​)∂∥​h+⋯−j​⊥​=ν1​∂⊥​h+⋯​(9.66)

The resulting equation of motion is

∂h(x,t)∂t=∂∥(αh−λ2h2)+(ν1+ν2)∂∥2h+ν1∂⊥2h+⋯+η(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial h(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\partial_{\|}\left(\alpha h-\frac{\lambda}{2} h^{2}\right)+\left(\nu_{1}+\nu_{2}\right) \partial_{\|}^{2} h+\nu_{1} \partial_{\perp}^{2} h+\cdots+\eta(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.67} \end{equation*}∂t∂h(x,t)​=∂∥​(αh−2λ​h2)+(ν1​+ν2​)∂∥2​h+ν1​∂⊥2​h+⋯+η(x,t)​(9.67)​

In the absence of external inputs and outputs (no rain, drainage, or exits), the noise is also conservative, with correlations,

⟨η(q,t)⟩=0, and ⟨η(q,t)η(q′,t′)⟩=2(D∥q∥2+D⊥q⊥2)δ(t−t′)(2π)dδd(q+q′)\begin{align*} \langle\eta(\mathbf{q}, t)\rangle=0, \quad \text { and } & \left\langle\eta(\mathbf{q}, t) \eta\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=2\left(D_{\|} q_{\|}^{2}+D_{\perp} q_{\perp}^{2}\right) \tag{9.68}\\ & \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right)(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) \end{align*}⟨η(q,t)⟩=0, and ​⟨η(q,t)η(q′,t′)⟩=2(D∥​q∥2​+D⊥​q⊥2​)δ(t−t′)(2π)dδd(q+q′)​(9.68)​

Note that the symmetries of the problem allow different noise correlations parallel and perpendicular to the net flow.

Equations (9.67) and (9.68) define a driven diffusion system (DDS) [H.K. Janssen and B. Schmittman, Z. Phys. B 63, 517 (1986); P.L.Garrido, J. L. Lebowitz, C. Maes, and H. Spohn, Phys. Rev. A 42, 1954 (1990); Z. Cheng, P.L. Garrido, J.L. Lebowitz, and J.L. Valles, Europhys. Lett. 14, 507 (1991)]. The first term in Eq. (9.67) can be eliminated by looking at fluctuations in a moving frame,

h(x∥,x⊥,t)→h(x∥−αt,x⊥,t)\begin{equation*} h\left(x_{\|}, \mathbf{x}_{\perp}, t\right) \rightarrow h\left(x_{\|}-\alpha t, \mathbf{x}_{\perp}, t\right) \tag{9.69} \end{equation*}h(x∥​,x⊥​,t)→h(x∥​−αt,x⊥​,t)​(9.69)​

and shall be ignored henceforth. Neglecting the non-linear terms at first, these fluctuations satisfy the anisotropic noisy diffusion equation

∂h(x,t)∂t=ν∥∂∥2h+ν⊥∂⊥2h+η(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial h(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\nu_{\|} \partial_{\|}^{2} h+\nu_{\perp} \partial_{\perp}^{2} h+\eta(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.70} \end{equation*}∂t∂h(x,t)​=ν∥​∂∥2​h+ν⊥​∂⊥2​h+η(x,t)​(9.70)​

where ν∥=ν1+ν2\nu_{\|}=\nu_{1}+\nu_{2}ν∥​=ν1​+ν2​ and ν⊥=ν1\nu_{\perp}=\nu_{1}ν⊥​=ν1​. The Fourier modes now relax with characteristic times,

τ(q)=1ν∥q∥2+ν⊥q⊥2\begin{equation*} \tau(\mathbf{q})=\frac{1}{\nu_{\|} q_{\|}^{2}+\nu_{\perp} q_{\perp}^{2}} \tag{9.71} \end{equation*}τ(q)=ν∥​q∥2​+ν⊥​q⊥2​1​​(9.71)​

Following the steps leading to Eq. (9.48),

lim⁡t→∞⟨∣h(q,t)∣2⟩=D∥q∥2+D⊥q⊥2ν∥q∥2+ν⊥q⊥2.\begin{equation*} \left.\left.\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty}\langle | h(\mathbf{q}, t)\right|^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{D_{\|} q_{\|}^{2}+D_{\perp} q_{\perp}^{2}}{\nu_{\|} q_{\|}^{2}+\nu_{\perp} q_{\perp}^{2}} . \tag{9.72} \end{equation*}t→∞lim​⟨∣h(q,t)​2⟩=ν∥​q∥2​+ν⊥​q⊥2​D∥​q∥2​+D⊥​q⊥2​​.​(9.72)​

The stationary correlation functions 2{ }^{2}2 in real space now behave as [G. Grinstein, S. Sachdev, and D.H. Lee, Phys. Rev. Lett. 64, 1927 (1990); P.L. Garrido, J. L. Lebowitz, C. Maes, and H. Spohn, Phys. Rev. A 42, 1954 (1990); Z. Cheng, P.L. Garrido, J.L. Lebowitz, and J.L. Valles, Europhys. Lett. 14, 507 (1991)].

⟨(h(x)−h(0))2⟩=∫dd−1q⊥dq∥(2π)d(2−2cos⁡(q∥x∥+q⊥⋅x⊥))D∥q∥2+D⊥q⊥2ν∥q∥2+ν⊥q⊥2∝(D⊥ν⊥−D∥ν∥)ν∥d−1ν⊥(ν⊥x∥2+ν∥x⊥2)d.\begin{align*} \left\langle(h(\mathbf{x})-h(\mathbf{0}))^{2}\right\rangle= & \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d-1} \mathbf{q}_{\perp} d q_{\|}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left(2-2 \cos \left(q_{\|} x_{\|}+\mathbf{q}_{\perp} \cdot \mathbf{x}_{\perp}\right)\right) \frac{D_{\|} q_{\|}^{2}+D_{\perp} q_{\perp}^{2}}{\nu_{\|} q_{\|}^{2}+\nu_{\perp} q_{\perp}^{2}} \\ & \propto\left(\frac{D_{\perp}}{\nu_{\perp}}-\frac{D_{\|}}{\nu_{\|}}\right) \sqrt{\frac{\nu_{\|}^{d-1} \nu_{\perp}}{\left(\nu_{\perp} x_{\|}^{2}+\nu_{\|} x_{\perp}^{2}\right)^{d}}} . \tag{9.73} \end{align*}⟨(h(x)−h(0))2⟩=​∫(2π)ddd−1q⊥​dq∥​​(2−2cos(q∥​x∥​+q⊥​⋅x⊥​))ν∥​q∥2​+ν⊥​q⊥2​D∥​q∥2​+D⊥​q⊥2​​∝(ν⊥​D⊥​​−ν∥​D∥​​)(ν⊥​x∥2​+ν∥​x⊥2​)dν∥d−1​ν⊥​​​.​(9.73)​

Note that these correlations are spatially extended and scale invariant. This is again a consequence of the conservation law. Only in the special case where D⊥/ν⊥=D∥/ν∥D_{\perp} / \nu_{\perp}=D_{\|} / \nu_{\|}D⊥​/ν⊥​=D∥​/ν∥​is the Einstein relation (D(q)∝ν(q))(D(\mathbf{q}) \propto \nu(\mathbf{q}))(D(q)∝ν(q)) satisfied, and the fluctuations become uncorrelated (C(x)∝δd(x)D/ν)\left(C(\mathbf{x}) \propto \delta^{d}(\mathbf{x}) D / \nu\right)(C(x)∝δd(x)D/ν). The results then correspond to model B dynamics with a Hamiltonian H∝∫ddxh2\mathcal{H} \propto \int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} h^{2}H∝∫ddxh2. This example illustrates the special nature of near equilibrium dynamics. The fluctuation-dissipation condition is needed to ensure approach to the equilibrium state where there is typically no scale invariance. On the other hand, removing this restriction leads to GSI in a conservative system. ( D⊥/ν⊥≠D∥/ν∥D_{\perp} / \nu_{\perp} \neq D_{\|} / \nu_{\|}D⊥​/ν⊥​=D∥​/ν∥​is like having two different temperatures parallel and perpendicular to the flow.)

Let us now break the conservation law stochastically by adding random inputs and outputs to the problem (in the form of rain, drainage, or exits). The properties of the noise are now modified to

⟨η(x,t)⟩=0, and ⟨η(x,t)η(x′,t′)⟩=2Dδ(x∥−x∥′)δd−1(x⊥−x⊥′)δ(t−t′).\begin{equation*} \langle\eta(\mathbf{x}, t)\rangle=0, \quad \text { and } \quad\left\langle\eta(\mathbf{x}, t) \eta\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=2 D \delta\left(x_{\|}-x_{\|}^{\prime}\right) \delta^{d-1}\left(\mathbf{x}_{\perp}-\mathbf{x}_{\perp}^{\prime}\right) \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) . \tag{9.7.7} \end{equation*}⟨η(x,t)⟩=0, and ⟨η(x,t)η(x′,t′)⟩=2Dδ(x∥​−x∥′​)δd−1(x⊥​−x⊥′​)δ(t−t′).​(9.7.7)​

[^8]In the stationary state,

lim⁡t→∞⟨∣h(q,t)∣2⟩=Dν∥q∥2+ν⊥q⊥2\begin{equation*} \left.\left.\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty}\langle | h(\mathbf{q}, t)\right|^{2}\right\rangle=\frac{D}{\nu_{\|} q_{\|}^{2}+\nu_{\perp} q_{\perp}^{2}} \tag{9.75} \end{equation*}t→∞lim​⟨∣h(q,t)​2⟩=ν∥​q∥2​+ν⊥​q⊥2​D​​(9.75)​

in Fourier space, and

⟨(h(x)−h(0))2⟩∝D(ν⊥x∥2+ν∥x⊥2)2−d2\begin{equation*} \left\langle(h(\mathbf{x})-h(\mathbf{0}))^{2}\right\rangle \propto D\left(\nu_{\perp} x_{\|}^{2}+\nu_{\|} x_{\perp}^{2}\right)^{\frac{2-d}{2}} \tag{9.76} \end{equation*}⟨(h(x)−h(0))2⟩∝D(ν⊥​x∥2​+ν∥​x⊥2​)22−d​​(9.76)​

in real space. Except for the anisotropy, this is the same result as in Eq. (9.61), with χ=(2−d)/2\chi=(2-d) / 2χ=(2−d)/2.

How are the results modified by the nonlinear term (−λ∂∥h2/2)\left(-\lambda \partial_{\|} h^{2} / 2\right)(−λ∂∥​h2/2) in Eq. (9.67)? We first perform a simple dimensional analysis by rescaling lengths and time. Allowing for anisotropic scalings, we set x∥→bx∥x_{\|} \rightarrow b x_{\|}x∥​→bx∥​, accompanied by t→bzt,x⃗⊥→bζx⃗⊥t \rightarrow b^{z} t, \vec{x}_{\perp} \rightarrow b^{\zeta} \vec{x}_{\perp}t→bzt,x⊥​→bζx⊥​, and h→bχhh \rightarrow b^{\chi} hh→bχh. Eq. (9.67) is now modified to

bχ−z∂h∂t=ν∥bχ−2∂∥2h+ν⊥bχ−2ζ∂⊥2h−λ2b2χ−1∂∥h2+b−z/2−(d−1)ξ/2−1/2η,\begin{equation*} b^{\chi-z} \frac{\partial h}{\partial t}=\nu_{\|} b^{\chi-2} \partial_{\|}^{2} h+\nu_{\perp} b^{\chi-2 \zeta} \partial_{\perp}^{2} h-\frac{\lambda}{2} b^{2 \chi-1} \partial_{\|} h^{2}+b^{-z / 2-(d-1) \xi / 2-1 / 2} \eta, \tag{9.77} \end{equation*}bχ−z∂t∂h​=ν∥​bχ−2∂∥2​h+ν⊥​bχ−2ζ∂⊥2​h−2λ​b2χ−1∂∥​h2+b−z/2−(d−1)ξ/2−1/2η,​(9.77)​

where Eq. (9.74) has been used to determine the scaling of η\etaη. We thus identify the bare scalings for these parameters as

{ν∥→bz−2ν∥ν⊥→bz−2ζν⊥λ→bχ+z−1λD→bz−2χ−ζ(d−1)−1D(9.78)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \nu_{\|} \rightarrow b^{z-2} \nu_{\|} \tag{9.78}\\ \nu_{\perp} \rightarrow b^{z-2 \zeta} \nu_{\perp} \\ \lambda \rightarrow b^{\chi+z-1} \lambda \\ D \rightarrow b^{z-2 \chi-\zeta(d-1)-1} D \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​ν∥​→bz−2ν∥​ν⊥​→bz−2ζν⊥​λ→bχ+z−1λD→bz−2χ−ζ(d−1)−1D​(9.78)

In the absence of λ\lambdaλ, the parameters can be made scale invariant (i.e. independent of bbb ) by the choice of ζ0=1,z0=2\zeta_{0}=1, z_{0}=2ζ0​=1,z0​=2, and χ0=(2−d)/2\chi_{0}=(2-d) / 2χ0​=(2−d)/2, as encountered before. However, with this choice, a small λ\lambdaλ will grow under rescaling as

λ→by0λ, with y0=4−d2.\begin{equation*} \lambda \rightarrow b^{y_{0}} \lambda, \quad \text { with } \quad y_{0}=\frac{4-d}{2} . \tag{9.79} \end{equation*}λ→by0​λ, with y0​=24−d​.​(9.79)​

Since the nonlinearity grows larger under scaling it cannot be ignored in dimensions d<4d<4d<4.

Equations (9.78) constitute a simple renormalization group (RG) that is valid close to the fixed point (scale invariant equation) corresponding to a linearized limit. To calculate the RG equations at finite values of nonlinearity in general requires a perturbative calculation. Sometimes there are exact nonrenormalization conditions that simplify the calculation and lead to exponent identities. Fortunately there are enough such identities for Eq. (9.77) that the three exponents can be obtained exactly. (1) As the nonlinearity is proportional to q∥q_{\|}q∥​in Fourier space, it does not generate under RG any contributions that can modify ν⊥\nu_{\perp}ν⊥​. The corresponding "bare" scaling of ν⊥\nu_{\perp}ν⊥​ in Eqs. (9.78) is thus always valid; its fixed point leads to the exponent identity z−2ζ=0z-2 \zeta=0z−2ζ=0. (2) As the nonlinearity is in the conservative part, it does not renormalize the strength of the non-conservative noise. The non-renormalization of DDD leads to the exponent identity z−2χ−ζ(d−1)−1=0z-2 \chi-\zeta(d-1)-1=0z−2χ−ζ(d−1)−1=0. (This condition has a natural counterpart in equilibrium model B dynamics, z−2χ−d−2=0z-2 \chi-d-2=0z−2χ−d−2=0, leading to the well known relation, z=4−ηz=4-\etaz=4−η.) (3) Equation (9.67) is invariant under an infinitesimal reparameterization x∥→x∥−x_{\|} \rightarrow x_{\|}-x∥​→x∥​− δλt,t→t\delta \lambda t, t \rightarrow tδλt,t→t, if h→h+δh \rightarrow h+\deltah→h+δ. Note that the parameter λ\lambdaλ appears both as the coefficient of the nonlinearity in Eq. (9.67) and as an invariant factor relating the x∥x_{\|}x∥​and hhh reparameterizations. Hence any renormalization of the driven diffusion equation that preserves this symmetry must leave the coefficient λ\lambdaλ unchanged, leading to the exponent identity z+χ−1=0z+\chi-1=0z+χ−1=0.

The remaining parameter, ν∥\nu_{\|}ν∥​, does indeed follow a non-trivial evolution under RG. However, the above three exponent identities are sufficient to give the exact exponents in all dimensions d≤4d \leq 4d≤4 as [T. Hwa and M. Kardar, Phys. Rev. A 45, 7002 (1992)]

χ=1−d7−d,z=67−d,ζ=37−d\begin{equation*} \chi=\frac{1-d}{7-d}, \quad z=\frac{6}{7-d}, \quad \zeta=\frac{3}{7-d} \tag{9.80} \end{equation*}χ=7−d1−d​,z=7−d6​,ζ=7−d3​​(9.80)​

9.6 Dynamics of a growing surface

The rapid growth of crystals by deposition, or molecular beam epitaxy, is an important technological process. It also provides the simplest example of a non-equilibrium evolution process [Dynamics of Fractal Surfaces, edited by F. Family and T. Vicsek, World Scientific, Singapore (1991)]. We would like to understand the dynamic scaling of fluctuations inherent to this type of growth. To construct the dependence of the local, deterministic velocity, vvv, on the surface height, h(x,t)h(\mathbf{x}, t)h(x,t), note that: (1) As long as the rearrangements of particles on the surface can result in holes and vacancies, there is no conservation law. (2) There is a translation symmetry, v[h(x)+c]=v[h(x)]v[h(\mathbf{x})+c]=v[h(\mathbf{x})]v[h(x)+c]=v[h(x)], implying that vvv depends only on gradients of h(x)h(\mathbf{x})h(x). (3) For simplicity, we shall focus on isotropic surfaces, in which all directions in x\mathbf{x}x are equivalent [See, however, D. Wolf, Phys. Rev. Lett. 67, 1783 (1991)]. (4) There is no up-down symmetry, i.e. v[h(x)]≠−v[−h(x)]v[h(\mathbf{x})] \neq-v[-h(\mathbf{x})]v[h(x)]=−v[−h(x)]. The absence of such symmetry allows addition of terms of both parities.

With these conditions, the lowest order terms in the equation of motion give [M. Kardar, G. Parisi, and Y.-C. Zhang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 56, 889 (1986); E. Medina, T. Hwa, M. Kardar, and Y.-C. Zhang, Phys. Rev. A 39, 3053 (1989)],

∂h(x,t)∂t=u+ν∇2h+λ2(∇h)2+⋯+η(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial h(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=u+\nu \nabla^{2} h+\frac{\lambda}{2}(\nabla h)^{2}+\cdots+\eta(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.81} \end{equation*}∂t∂h(x,t)​=u+ν∇2h+2λ​(∇h)2+⋯+η(x,t)​(9.81)​

with the non-conservative noise satisfying the correlations in Eq. (9.74).

In Eq. (9.81), uuu is related to the average growth velocity. In fact, the coefficients of all even terms must be proportional to uuu as they all vanish in the symmetric case with no preferred growth direction. The constant uuu is easily removed by transforming to a moving frame, h→h−uth \rightarrow h-u th→h−ut, and will be ignored henceforth. The first non-trivial term is the nonlinear contribution, λ(∇h)2/2\lambda(\nabla h)^{2} / 2λ(∇h)2/2. Geometrically this term can be justified by noting that growth by addition of particles proceeds through a parallel transport of the surface gradient in the normal direction. (See the inset to Fig. 9.1.) This term cannot be generated from the variations of any Hamiltonian, i.e. v≠−μδH[h]/δhv \neq-\mu \delta \mathcal{H}[h] / \delta hv=−μδH[h]/δh. Thus, contrary to the equilibrium situation (Noether's theorem), the translational symmetry does not imply a conservation law, v≠−∇jv \neq-\nabla jv=−∇j.

Further evidence of the relevance of Eq. (9.81) to growth phenomena is provided by examining deterministic growth. Consider a slow and uniform snowfall, on an initial profile which at t=0t=0t=0 is described by h0(x)h_{0}(\mathbf{x})h0​(x). The nonlinear equation can in fact be linearized with the aid of a "Cole-Hopf" transformation,

W(x,t)=exp⁡[λ2νh(x,t)].\begin{equation*} W(\mathbf{x}, t)=\exp \left[\frac{\lambda}{2 \nu} h(\mathbf{x}, t)\right] . \tag{9.82} \end{equation*}W(x,t)=exp[2νλ​h(x,t)].​(9.82)​

The function W(x,t)W(\mathbf{x}, t)W(x,t) evolves according to the diffusion equation with multiplicative noise,

∂W(x,t)∂t=ν∇2W+λ2νWη(x,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial W(\mathbf{x}, t)}{\partial t}=\nu \nabla^{2} W+\frac{\lambda}{2 \nu} W \eta(\mathbf{x}, t) \tag{9.83} \end{equation*}∂t∂W(x,t)​=ν∇2W+2νλ​Wη(x,t)​(9.83)​

In the absence of noise, η(x,t)=0\eta(\mathbf{x}, t)=0η(x,t)=0, Eq. (9.83) can be solved subject to the initial condition W(x,t=0)=exp⁡[λh0(x)/2ν]W(\mathbf{x}, t=0)=\exp \left[\lambda h_{0}(\mathbf{x}) / 2 \nu\right]W(x,t=0)=exp[λh0​(x)/2ν], and leads to the growth profile,

h(x,t)=2νλln⁡{∫ ddx′exp⁡[−∣x−x′∣22νt+λ2νh(x,t)]}.\begin{equation*} h(\mathbf{x}, t)=\frac{2 \nu}{\lambda} \ln \left\{\int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \exp \left[-\frac{\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{2}}{2 \nu t}+\frac{\lambda}{2 \nu} h(\mathbf{x}, t)\right]\right\} . \tag{9.84} \end{equation*}h(x,t)=λ2ν​ln{∫ ddx′exp[−2νt∣x−x′∣2​+2νλ​h(x,t)]}.​(9.84)​

It is instructive to examine the ν→0\nu \rightarrow 0ν→0 limit, which is indeed appropriate to snow falls since there is not much rearrangement after deposition. In this limit, the integral in Eq. (9.84) can be performed by the saddle point method. For each x\mathbf{x}x we have to identify a point x′\mathbf{x}^{\prime}x′ which maximizes the exponent, leading to a collection of paraboloids described by

h(x,t)=max⁡{h0(x′)−∣x−x′∣22λt}x′.\begin{equation*} h(\mathbf{x}, t)=\max \left\{h_{0}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)-\frac{\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{2}}{2 \lambda t}\right\}_{\mathbf{x}^{\prime}} . \tag{9.85} \end{equation*}h(x,t)=max{h0​(x′)−2λt∣x−x′∣2​}x′​.​(9.85)​

Such parabolic sequences are quite common in many layer by layer growth processes in nature, from biological to geological formations. The patterns for λ=1\lambda=1λ=1 are identical to those obtained by the geometrical method of Huygens, familiar from optics. The growth profile (wave front) is constructed from the outer envelope of circles of radius λt\lambda tλt drawn from all points on the initial profile. The nonlinearity in Eq. (9.81) algebraically captures this process of expanding wave fronts.

As growth proceeds, the surface smoothens by the coarsening of the parabolas. What is the typical size of these features at time ttt ? In maximizing the exponent in Eq. (9.85), we have to balance a reduction ∣x−x′∣2/2λt\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|^{2} / 2 \lambda t∣x−x′∣2/2λt, by a

Fig. 9.1 Deterministic growth according to Eq. (9.81) leads to a pattern of coarsening paraboloids. In one dimension, the slope of the interface forms "shock fronts". Inset depicts projection of lateral growth on the vertical direction. possible gain from h0(x′)h_{0}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)h0​(x′) in selecting a point away from x\mathbf{x}x. The final scaling is controlled by the roughness of the initial profile. Let us assume that the original pattern is a self-affine fractal of roughness χ\chiχ, i.e.

∣h0(x)−h0(x′)∣‾∼∣x−x′∣χ.\begin{equation*} \overline{\left|h_{0}(\mathbf{x})-h_{0}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right|} \sim\left|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right|{ }^{\chi} . \tag{9.86} \end{equation*}∣h0​(x)−h0​(x′)∣​∼∣x−x′∣χ.​(9.86)​

(According to Mandelbrot, χ≈0.7\chi \approx 0.7χ≈0.7 for mountains [B.B. Mandelbrot, The Fractal Geometry of Nature (Freeman, San Francisco, 1982)].) Balancing the two terms in Eq. (9.85) gives

(δx)χ∼(δx)2t⟹δx∼t1/z, with z+χ=2\begin{equation*} (\delta x)^{\chi} \sim \frac{(\delta x)^{2}}{t} \Longrightarrow \delta x \sim t^{1 / z}, \quad \text { with } \quad z+\chi=2 \tag{9.87} \end{equation*}(δx)χ∼t(δx)2​⟹δx∼t1/z, with z+χ=2​(9.87)​

For example, if the initial profile is like a random walk in d=1,χ=1/2d=1, \chi=1 / 2d=1,χ=1/2, and z=3/2z=3 / 2z=3/2. This leads to the spreading of information along the profile by a process that is faster than diffusion, δx∼t2/3\delta x \sim t^{2 / 3}δx∼t2/3.

Note that the slope, v⃗(x,t)=−λ∇⃗h(x,t)\vec{v}(\mathbf{x}, t)=-\lambda \vec{\nabla} h(x, t)v(x,t)=−λ∇h(x,t), satisfies the equation,

Dv⃗(x,t)Dt≡∂v⃗∂t+v⃗⋅∇⃗v⃗=ν∇2v⃗−λ∇η\begin{equation*} \frac{D \vec{v}(\mathbf{x}, t)}{D t} \equiv \frac{\partial \vec{v}}{\partial t}+\vec{v} \cdot \vec{\nabla} \vec{v}=\nu \nabla^{2} \vec{v}-\lambda \nabla \eta \tag{9.88} \end{equation*}DtDv(x,t)​≡∂t∂v​+v⋅∇v=ν∇2v−λ∇η​(9.88)​

The above is the Navier-Stokes equation for the velocity of a fluid of viscosity ν\nuν, which is being randomly stirred by a conservative force [D. Forster, D.R. Nelson, and M.J. Stephen, Phys. Rev. A 16, 732 (1977)], f⃗=−λ∇η\vec{f}=-\lambda \nabla \etaf​=−λ∇η. However, the fluid is vorticity free since

Ω⃗=∇⃗×v⃗=−λ∇×∇h=0.\begin{equation*} \vec{\Omega}=\vec{\nabla} \times \vec{v}=-\lambda \nabla \times \nabla h=0 . \tag{9.89} \end{equation*}Ω=∇×v=−λ∇×∇h=0.​(9.89)​

This is the Burgers equation [J.M. Burgers, The Nonlinear Diffusion Equation (Riedel, Boston, 1974)], which provides a simple example of the formation of shock waves in a fluid. The gradient of Eq. (9.85) in d=1d=1d=1 gives a saw tooth pattern of shocks which coarsen in time. Further note that in d=1d=1d=1, Eq. (9.88) is also equivalent to the driven diffusion equation of (9.67), with v⃗\vec{v}v playing the role of hhh.

To study stochastic roughening in the presence of the nonlinear term, we carry out a scaling analysis as in Eq. (9.77). Under the scaling x→bx,t→bzt\mathbf{x} \rightarrow b \mathbf{x}, t \rightarrow b^{z} tx→bx,t→bzt, and h→bχhh \rightarrow b^{\chi} hh→bχh, Eq. (9.81) transforms to

bχ−z∂h∂t=νbχ−2∇2h+λ2b2χ−2(∇h)2+η(bx,bzt)\begin{equation*} b^{\chi-z} \frac{\partial h}{\partial t}=\nu b^{\chi-2} \nabla^{2} h+\frac{\lambda}{2} b^{2 \chi-2}(\nabla h)^{2}+\eta\left(b \mathbf{x}, b^{z} t\right) \tag{9.90} \end{equation*}bχ−z∂t∂h​=νbχ−2∇2h+2λ​b2χ−2(∇h)2+η(bx,bzt)​(9.90)​

The correlations of the transformed noise, η′(x,t)=bz−χη(bx,bzt)\eta^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}, t)=b^{z-\chi} \eta\left(b \mathbf{x}, b^{z} t\right)η′(x,t)=bz−χη(bx,bzt), satisfy

⟨η′(x,t)η′(x′,t′)⟩=b2z−2χ2Dδd(x−x′)b−dδ(t−t′)b−z=bz−d−2χ2Dδd(x−x′)δ(t−t′)\begin{align*} \left\langle\eta^{\prime}(\mathbf{x}, t) \eta^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle & =b^{2 z-2 \chi} 2 D \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) b^{-d} \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) b^{-z} \\ & =b^{z-d-2 \chi} 2 D \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) \tag{9.91} \end{align*}⟨η′(x,t)η′(x′,t′)⟩​=b2z−2χ2Dδd(x−x′)b−dδ(t−t′)b−z=bz−d−2χ2Dδd(x−x′)δ(t−t′)​(9.91)​

Following this scaling the parameters of Eq. (9.81) are transformed to

{ν→bz−2νλ→bχ+z−2λD→bz−2χ−dD(9.92)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \nu \rightarrow b^{z-2} \nu \tag{9.92}\\ \lambda \rightarrow b^{\chi+z-2} \lambda \\ D \rightarrow b^{z-2 \chi-d} D \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​ν→bz−2νλ→bχ+z−2λD→bz−2χ−dD​(9.92)

For λ=0\lambda=0λ=0, the equation is made scale invariant upon the choice of z0=2z_{0}=2z0​=2, and χ0=(2−d)/2\chi_{0}=(2-d) / 2χ0​=(2−d)/2. Close to this linear fixed point, λ\lambdaλ scales to bz0+χ0−2λ=b^{z_{0}+\chi_{0}-2} \lambda=bz0​+χ0​−2λ= b(2−d)/2λb^{(2-d) / 2} \lambdab(2−d)/2λ, and is a relevant operator for d<2d<2d<2. In fact a perturbative dynamic renormalization group suggests that it is marginally relevant at d=2d=2d=2, and that in all dimensions a sufficiently large λ\lambdaλ leads to new scaling behavior. (This will be discussed further in the next chapter.)

Are there any non-renormalization conditions that can help in identifying the exponents of the full nonlinear stochastic equation? Note that since Eqs. (9.81) and (9.88) are related by a simple transformation, they must have the same scaling properties. Since the Navier-Stokes equation is derivable from Newton's laws of motion for fluid particles, it has the Galilean invariance of changing to a uniformly moving coordinate frame. This symmetry is preserved under renormalization to larger scales and requires that the ratio of the two terms on the left-hand side of Eq. (9.88) (∂tv⃗\left(\partial_{t} \vec{v}\right.(∂t​v and v⃗⋅∇v⃗)\left.\vec{v} \cdot \nabla \vec{v}\right)v⋅∇v) stays at unity. In terms of Eq. (9.81) this implies the non-renormalization of the parameter λ\lambdaλ, and leads to the exponent identity

χ+z=2\begin{equation*} \chi+z=2 \tag{9.93} \end{equation*}χ+z=2​(9.93)​

Unfortunately there is no other non-renormalization condition except in d=1d=1d=1. Following Eq. (9.36), we can write down a Fokker-Planck equation for the evolution of the configurational probability as,

∂P([h(x)],t)∂t=−∫ddxδδh(x)[(ν∇2h+λ2(∇h)2)P−DδPδh(x)]\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \mathcal{P}([h(\mathbf{x})], t)}{\partial t}=-\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \frac{\delta}{\delta h(\mathbf{x})}\left[\left(\nu \nabla^{2} h+\frac{\lambda}{2}(\nabla h)^{2}\right) \mathcal{P}-D \frac{\delta \mathcal{P}}{\delta h(\mathbf{x})}\right] \tag{9.94} \end{equation*}∂t∂P([h(x)],t)​=−∫ddxδh(x)δ​[(ν∇2h+2λ​(∇h)2)P−Dδh(x)δP​]​(9.94)​

Since Eq. (9.81) was not constructed from a Hamiltonian, in general we do not know the stationary solution at long times. In d=1d=1d=1, we make a guess and try a solution of the form

P0[h(x)]∝exp⁡[−ν2D∫ dx(∂xh)2].\begin{equation*} \mathcal{P}_{0}[h(x)] \propto \exp \left[-\frac{\nu}{2 D} \int \mathrm{~d} x\left(\partial_{x} h\right)^{2}\right] . \tag{9.95} \end{equation*}P0​[h(x)]∝exp[−2Dν​∫ dx(∂x​h)2].​(9.95)​

Since

δP0δh(x)=−∂xδP0δ(∂xh)=νD(∂x2h)P0,\begin{equation*} \frac{\delta \mathcal{P}_{0}}{\delta h(x)}=-\partial_{x} \frac{\delta \mathcal{P}_{0}}{\delta\left(\partial_{x} h\right)}=\frac{\nu}{D}\left(\partial_{x}^{2} h\right) \mathcal{P}_{0}, \tag{9.96} \end{equation*}δh(x)δP0​​=−∂x​δ(∂x​h)δP0​​=Dν​(∂x2​h)P0​,​(9.96)​

Eq. (9.94) leads to,

∂P0∂t=−∫dxδP0δh(x)(ν∂x2h+λ2(∂xh)2−DνD∂x2h)=−λ2P0∫ dxνD(∂x2h)(∂xh)2=−λν2DP0∫ dx∂x((∂xh)33)=0\begin{align*} \frac{\partial \mathcal{P}_{0}}{\partial t} & =-\int \mathrm{d} x \frac{\delta \mathcal{P}_{0}}{\delta h(x)}\left(\nu \partial_{x}^{2} h+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left(\partial_{x} h\right)^{2}-D \frac{\nu}{D} \partial_{x}^{2} h\right) \\ & =-\frac{\lambda}{2} \mathcal{P}_{0} \int \mathrm{~d} x \frac{\nu}{D}\left(\partial_{x}^{2} h\right)\left(\partial_{x} h\right)^{2}=-\frac{\lambda \nu}{2 D} \mathcal{P}_{0} \int \mathrm{~d} x \partial_{x}\left(\frac{\left(\partial_{x} h\right)^{3}}{3}\right)=0 \tag{9.97} \end{align*}∂t∂P0​​​=−∫dxδh(x)δP0​​(ν∂x2​h+2λ​(∂x​h)2−DDν​∂x2​h)=−2λ​P0​∫ dxDν​(∂x2​h)(∂x​h)2=−2Dλν​P0​∫ dx∂x​(3(∂x​h)3​)=0​(9.97)​

We have thus identified the stationary state of the one dimensional equation. (This procedure does not work in higher dimensions as it is impossible to write the final result as a total derivative.) Surprisingly, the stationary distribution is the same as the one in equilibrium at a temperature proportional to D/νD / \nuD/ν. We can thus immediately identify the roughness exponent χ=1/2\chi=1 / 2χ=1/2, which together with the exponent identity in Eq. (9.93) leads to z=3/2z=3 / 2z=3/2, i.e. superdiffusive behavior.

The values of the exponents in the strongly nonlinear regime are not known exactly in higher dimensions. However, extensive numerical simulations of growth have provided fairly reliable estimates [Dynamics of Fractal Surfaces, edited by F. Family and T. Vicsek, World Scientific, Singapore (1991)]. In the physically relevant case (d=2)(d=2)(d=2) of a surface grown in three dimensions, χ≈0.39\chi \approx 0.39χ≈0.39 and z≈1.61z \approx 1.61z≈1.61 [B.M. Forrest and L.-H. Tang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 64, 1405 (1990)]. A rather good (but not exact) fit to the exponents in a general dimension ddd is the following estimate by Kim and Kosterlitz [J.M. Kim and J.M. Kosterlitz, Phys. Rev. Lett. 62, 2289 (1989)],

χ≈2d+3 and z≈2(d+2)d+3.\begin{equation*} \chi \approx \frac{2}{d+3} \quad \text { and } \quad z \approx \frac{2(d+2)}{d+3} . \tag{9.98} \end{equation*}χ≈d+32​ and z≈d+32(d+2)​.​(9.98)​
